children.label: mesosphere
children.definition: The atmospheric shell, in which temperature generally decreases with heights, extending from the stratopause at about 50 to 55 kilometers to the mesopause at about 80 to 85 kilometers.

children.label: exosphere
children.definition: The outermost, or topmost, portion of the atmosphere. Its lower boundary is the critical level of escape, variously estimated at 500 to 1000 kilometers above the Earth's surface.

children.label: thermosphere
children.definition: It is the portion of the Earth's atmosphere between mesosphere and exosphere. It is the biggest of all the layers of the Earth's atmosphere.

children.label: troposphere
children.definition: That portion of the atmosphere from the Earth's surface to the stratosphere; that is, the lowest 10 to 20 kilometers of the atmosphere. The troposphere is characterized by decreasing temperature with height, appreciable vertical wind motion, appreciable water vapor content, and weather. Dynamically, the troposphere can be divided into the following layers: surface boundary layer, Ekman layer, and free atmosphere.

children.label: stratosphere
children.definition: Region of the atmosphere between the troposphere and mesosphere, having a lower boundary about 8 km. at the poles to 15 km. at the equator and an upper boundary of about 50 km.

children.label: ozonosphere
children.definition: The general stratum of the upper atmosphere in which there is an appreciable ozone concentration and in which ozone plays an important part in the radiation balance of the atmosphere. This region lies roughly between 10 and 50 kilometers, with maximum ozone concentration at about 20 to 25 kilometers. Used for ozone layer.

children.label: radiative forcing
children.definition: A change in the balance between incoming solar radiation and outgoing infrared radiation. Without any radiative forcing, solar radiation coming to the Earth would continue to be approximately equal to the infrared radiation emitted from the Earth. The addition of greenhouse gases traps an increased fraction of the infrared radiation, radiating it back toward the surface and creating a warming influence (i.e., positive radiative forcing because incoming solar radiation will exceed outgoing infrared radiation).

children.label: net radiation
children.definition: Earth's net radiation, sometimes called net flux, is the balance between incoming and outgoing energy at the top of the atmosphere. It is the total energy that is available to influence the climate.

children.label: greenhouse effect
children.definition: Trapping and build-up of heat in the atmosphere (troposphere) near the Earth's surface. Some of the heat flowing back toward space from the Earth's surface is absorbed by water vapor, carbon dioxide, ozone, and several other gases in the atmosphere and then reradiated back toward the Earth's surface. If the atmospheric concentrations of these greenhouse gases rise, the average temperature of the lower atmosphere will gradually increase.

children.label: greenhouse gases
children.definition: Those gases, such as water vapor, carbon dioxide, tropospheric ozone, nitrous oxide, and methane, that are transparent to solar radiation but opaque to longwave radiation. Their action is similar to that of glass in a greenhouse.

children.label: airshed
children.definition: A region with common sources and problems of air pollution; it may coincide with a watershed or be a part of a large urban agglomeration.

children.label: atmospheric chemistry
children.definition: Study of the production, transport, modification, and removal of atmospheric constituents in the troposphere and stratosphere.

children.label: climate
children.definition: The composite or generally prevailing weather conditions of a region, throughout the year, averaged over a series of years.

children.label: microclimate
children.definition: The local climate of a given site or habitat varying in size from a tiny crevice to a large land area, but being usually characterized by considerable uniformity of climate over the site involved and relatively local as compared to its enveloping macroclimate from which it differs because of local climatic factors (such as elevation and exposure).

children.label: humid zones
children.definition: Regions where the average relative humidity is high, and the precipitation is sufficient to support forests.

children.label: subhumid zones
children.definition: Regions where the climate is intermediate between semiarid and humid, and the precipitation supports dense growth of tall or short grasses, but not forests.

children.label: Mediterranean climate
children.definition: Climate typical of, but not exclusive to, the Mediterranean region with cool, moist winters and warm, dry summers.

children.label: maritime climate
children.definition: A fairly humid climate with small and mild annual temperature range that typically occurs in a region influenced by oceanic airflow.

children.label: tropics
children.definition: Tropical moist climates extend north and south from the equator to about 15° to 25° latitude. In these climates all months have average temperatures greater than 64°F (18°C) and annual precipitation greater than 59".

children.label: dry climates
children.definition: The most obvious climatic feature of this climate is that potential evaporation and transpiration exceed precipitation. These climates extend from 20°-35° North and South of the equator and in large continental regions of the mid-latitudes often surrounded by mountains.

children.label: arid zones
children.definition: Dry climatic type with less than 10 inches of precipitation per year.

children.label: semiarid zones
children.definition: Regions characterized by low and erratic rainfall, periods of drought, and where the prevalent vegetation is scattered short grasses, bunchgrasses or shrubs.

children.label: cold zones
children.definition: Polar climates have year-round cold temperatures with the warmest month less than 50°F (10°C). Polar climates are found on the northern coastal areas of North America, Europe, Asia, and on the land masses of Greenland and Antarctica.

children.label: meteorology
children.definition: The study dealing with the phenomena of the atmosphere especially as they relate to weather and climate. Used for atmospheric conditions.

children.label: climatology
children.definition: Branch of meteorology that studies the average weather conditions and statistical variations for a specified region over an extended period of time.

children.label: paleoclimatology
children.definition: The study of climates in the geologic past, involving fossil, glacial, isotropic, or other data.

children.label: bioclimatology
children.definition: The effects of climate on living organisms.

children.label: weather
children.definition: The state of the atmosphere at a definite time and place with respect to air temperature, humidity, wind, precipitation, cloudiness, etc.

children.label: fire weather
children.definition: Weather parameters (e.g., precipitation, relative humidity, windspeed and direction, etc.) that influence fire occurrence and subsequent fire behavior.

children.label: floods
children.definition: An overflow or inundation that comes from a river or other body of water and causes or threatens to cause property damage.

children.label: humidity
children.definition: A measure of the amount of water vapor present in the air.

children.label: relative humidity
children.definition: Ratio of the amount of water vapor present in the air to that which the air would hold at saturation at the same temperature. It is usually considered on the basis of the weight of the vapor but, for accuracy, should be considered on the basis of vapor pressures.

children.label: trade winds
children.definition: Persistent tropical winds that blow from the subtropical high pressure centers towards the equatorial low.

children.label: effective precipitation
children.definition: Effective precipitation is defined as the difference between total precipitation (rainfall) and potential runoff, evapotranspiration.

children.label: throughfall
children.definition: All the precipitation reaching the forest floor minus the stemflow, i.e., canopy drip plus direct precipitation.

children.label: stemflow
children.definition: Precipitation that is intercepted by vegetative cover and runs down the stem or major axes of such cover.

children.label: dewpoint
children.definition: The temperature at which a vapor begins to deposit as a liquid. Applies especially to water in the atmosphere.

children.label: vapor pressure deficit
children.definition: The difference between the observed vapor pressure and the saturation vapor pressure in the air.

children.label: atmospheric pressure
children.definition: The total pressure exerted by the atmosphere of Earth.

children.label: direct solar radiation
children.definition: The solar radiation that passes through the atmosphere and reaches Earth directly without any absorption or scattering by the atmospheric particulates or molecules.

children.label: diffuse solar radiation
children.definition: Diffuse solar radiation is that fraction of the solar radiation that is reaching Earth's surface after been scattered downwards by the molecules or particulates in the atmosphere.

children.label: La Nina
children.definition: La Niña, a phase of El Niño-Southern Oscillation, is a periodic cooling of surface ocean waters in the eastern tropical Pacific along with a shift in convection in the western Pacific further west than the climatological average. These conditions affect weather patterns around the world.

children.label: El Nino
children.definition: A warming of the ocean current along the coasts of Peru and Ecuador that is generally associated with dramatic changes in the weather patterns of the region; a major El Niño event generally occurs every 3 to 7 years and is associated with changes in the weather patterns worldwide.

children.label: General Circulation Models
children.definition: Hydrodynamic models of the atmosphere on a grid or spectral resolution that determine the surface pressure and the vertical distributions of velocity, temperature, density, and water vapor as functions of time from the mass conservation and hydrostatic laws, the first law of thermodynamics, Newton's second law of motion, the equation of state, and the conservation law for water vapor. Abbreviated as GCM. Atmospheric general circulation models are abbreviated AGCM, while oceanic general circulation models are abbreviated OGCM.

children.label: growing season
children.definition: Determined by climate, geographical location, and crop selection, the period of the year in which crops grow best.

children.label: environmental sustainability
children.definition: Long-term maintenance of ecosystem components and functions for future generations.

children.label: sustainable engineering
children.definition: The design, commercialization and use of processes and products that are feasible and economical while reducing the generation of pollution at the source and minimizing the risk to human health and the environment.

children.label: life cycle engineering
children.definition: A process to develop specifications to meet a set of performance, cost, and environmental requirements and goals that span the product, system, process, or facility life cycle.

children.label: life cycle design
children.definition: Life cycle design incorporates environmental impact considerations into each phase of product design so the ultimate impacts of the product are minimized and optimized with both economic and physical performance.

children.label: energy recovery
children.definition: Saving or recovering energy which would otherwise be loss from processing or waste.

children.label: urban mining
children.definition: Systematic recovery or recycling of electronic and other related waste materials or compounds of commercial interest from urban sites.

children.label: advanced wastewater treatment
children.definition: Any treatment of sewage that goes beyond the secondary or biological water treatment stage and includes the removal of nutrients such as phosphorus and nitrogen and a high percentage of suspended solids.

children.label: composting
children.definition: The biodecomposition of organic material, such as animal wastes, plant residues or sludges, in the presence of air, by controlled methods including mechanical mixing and aerating.

children.label: home composting
children.definition: Refers to the diversion of food scraps and yard trimmings from the municipal waste stream through the onsite controlled decomposition of organic matter by micro-organisms (mainly bacteria and fungi) into a humus-like product. Backyard composting is excluded from recycling activities. Rather, it is considered source reduction because the composted materials never enter the municipal solid waste stream.

children.label: producer responsibility
children.definition: Policy measure requiring manufacturers to be responsible for design, management, and financing programs that improve end-of-life/postconsumer management for their product and related packaging.

children.label: design for environment
children.definition: Design approach emphasizing sustainability principles which aims to lessen the environmental impact of a product or process.

children.label: ecological footprint
children.definition: An ecological footprint is a measurement of the area, whether land- or water-based, required to support a certain level and/or type of consumption by an enterprise, activity, individual or population. The footprint calculation assesses the resources (e.g.the amount of water, energy, nutrients or land, [natural capital]) required for the production of what is being consumed and the resources required to assimilate the resulting waste.

children.label: water footprint
children.definition: A measure of the total freshwater consumed and/or polluted by individuals, communities, governments, or enterprises that use water as producers or consumers of goods and services. The water footprint serves as a sustainability indicator and decision tool for water management.

children.label: carbon footprint
children.definition: A measure of the total set of greenhouse gas emissions, usually expressed in terms of the amount of carbon dioxide emissions (CO2 equivalent), that is directly and indirectly produced by the activities of individuals, households, populations, governments, businesses, organizations or service sectors, or accumulated over a product life cycle.

children.label: sustainable development
children.definition: Economic development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

children.label: sustainable agriculture
children.definition: An integrated system of plant and animal production practices having a site-specific application that will, over the long-term— (A) satisfy human food and fiber needs; (B) enhance environmental quality and the natural resource base upon which the agriculture economy depends; (C) make the most efficient use of nonrenewable resources and on-farm resources and integrate, where appropriate, natural biological cycles and controls; (D) sustain the economic viability of farm operations; and (E) enhance the quality of life for farmers and society as a whole.

children.label: community supported agriculture
children.definition: Community Supported Agriculture consists of a community of individuals who pledge support to a farm operation so that the farmland becomes, either legally or spiritually, the community's farm, with the growers and consumers providing mutual support and sharing the risks and benefits of food production.

children.label: good agricultural practices
children.definition: Guidelines and methods for farmers, growers, food producers, and those involved in agriculture to manage the resources important to agriculture, such as soil, water, and air, to produce safe and hygienic food products with commitment to sustainability and conservation, while protecting human and animal health and welfare as well as the environment.

children.label: sustainable agricultural intensification
children.definition: Sustainable crop production intensification provides opportunities for optimizing crop production per unit area, taking into consideration the range of sustainability aspects including potential and/or real social, political, economic and environmental impacts.

children.label: crop diversification
children.definition: Crop diversification is defined as the strategy of shifting from less profitable to more profitable crops, changing of variety and cropping system, increasing exports and competitiveness in both domestic and international markets, protecting the environment, and making conditions favorable for combining Agriculture-Fishery-Forestry-Livestock. Crop diversification can be a useful means to increase crop output under different situations.

children.label: sustainable land management
children.definition: A process for the management of land resources that meets present needs without compromising future ecosystem services and land productivity.

children.label: sustainable communities
children.definition: A community that is environmentally, economically, and socially healthy and resilient through management of its natural, financial, and human resources to meet current needs while ensuring that sufficient resources are equitably available into the future.

children.label: industrial ecology
children.definition: The systematic study of material and energy flows in products, industrial processes, and economies focusing on the interaction of industrial systems and the ecological systems of which they are a part.

children.label: eco-efficiency
children.definition: The relationship between economic outputs of products, processes and services and their environmental impact, with the goal being efficient use of materials and energy throughout the life cycle in order to reduce economic and ecological costs.

children.label: life cycle thinking
children.definition: LCT is a concept that integrates existing consumption and production strategies, preventing a piece-meal approach. LCT and other approaches can be used to improve the way we think about problem solving and use available information. Life cycle approaches help avoid shifting problems from one life cycle stage to another, from one geographic area to another and from one environmental medium (air, water, soil) to another.

children.label: materials life cycle
children.definition: All the stages involved in management of materials, including manufacture, processing, distribution, use, maintenance, recycling and disposal.

children.label: closed loop systems
children.definition: An ecological or industrial system in which energy and material are conserved.

children.label: systems analysis
children.definition: The formal study of complex systems carried out to support decision making. Systems analysis examines the implementation and impacts of alternative technologies or courses of action considering the probable consequences of the alternatives in terms of uncertainty, risk, costs, and benefits. Systems analysis requires interdisciplinary approaches to guide decisions on public and private strategy and programs, resource use and protection, research and development in technology, regional and urban development, educational systems, and health and other social services.

children.label: system optimization
children.definition: The procedure used in the design of a system to maximize or minimize some performance index. May entail the selection of a component, a principle of operation, or a technique.

children.label: linear programming
children.definition: An optimization problem characterization in which a set of parameter values are to be determined, subject to given linear constraints.

children.label: dynamic programming
children.definition: Algorithmic technique used for solving an optimization problem by caching subproblem solutions (memoization) rather than recomputing them.

children.label: life cycle design
children.definition: Life cycle design incorporates environmental impact considerations into each phase of product design so the ultimate impacts of the product are minimized and optimized with both economic and physical performance.

children.label: material flow analysis
children.definition: A systematic evaluation of how materials and energy flow through a defined system.

children.label: life cycle assessment
children.definition: A technique to assess the environmental aspects and potential impacts associated with a product, process, or service, by: compiling an inventory of relevant energy and material inputs and environmental releases [outputs]; evaluating the potential environmental impacts associated with identified inputs and releases [outputs]; interpreting the results to help you make a more informed decision.

children.label: LCA foreground system
children.definition: The foreground system consists of processes which are under the control of the decision-maker for which an LCA (Life cycle assessment) is carried out.

children.label: life cycle impact assessment
children.definition: The phase of life cycle assessment which evaluates potential environmental impacts of a product, process, or system throughout its life cycle.

children.label: emissions factor
children.definition: A unique value for scaling emissions to activity data in terms of a standard rate of emissions per unit of activity (e.g., grams of carbon dioxide emitted per barrel of fossil fuel consumed, or per pound of product produced).

children.label: midpoint indicator
children.definition: A point in the cause-effect chain (environmental mechanism) of a particular impact category, prior to the endpoint, at which characterization factors can be calculated to reflect the relative importance of an emission or extraction in a Life Cycle Inventory (LCI).

children.label: endpoint indicator
children.definition: Final point in the cause-effect chain of a particular impact category.

children.label: intermediate product
children.definition: Unit process output which requires additional transformation as a contribution to a product flow.

children.label: reference flow (life cycle assessment)
children.definition: Quantity of outputs from processes in a given product system required to fulfill the function expressed by the functional unit.

children.label: gate-to-gate
children.definition: A system boundary condition in a life cycle assessment which describes raw or intermediate material processing within the farm or factory gates.

children.label: life cycle inventory
children.definition: A process of quantifying energy and raw material requirements, atmospheric emissions, waterborne emissions, solid wastes, and other releases for the entire life cycle of a product, process, or activity. Life cycle inventory is a phase of life cycle assessment.

children.label: functional unit (life cycle assessment)
children.definition: Life cycle assessments are organized in terms of a functional unit that appropriately describes the function of the product(s) or process(es) being studied and/or compared.

children.label: co-product allocation
children.definition: Objectively assigning resource use, energy consumption, and emissions to identified co-products where there is no physical or chemical way to separate the activities that produce them.

children.label: product system
children.definition: In life cycle assessment, the entire set of processes (unit operations) undergone by a product from production to disposal.

children.label: cut-off criteria (life cycle assessment)
children.definition: Quantification of the material or energy exchanges or the level of environmental impact associated with unit processes or product system excluded from a study.

children.label: elementary flow
children.definition: Material or energy entering or leaving the system being studied, which has been drawn from or emitted to the environment without previous or subsequent human transformation.

children.label: LCA background system
children.definition: The background system consists of processes on which no or, at best, indirect influence may be exercised by the decision-maker for which an LCA (Life cycle assessment) is carried out.

children.label: attributional life cycle assessment
children.definition: A life cycle modeling method that describes flows of material, energy and emissions within a discrete product or system.

children.label: cradle-to-cradle
children.definition: A system boundary condition in a life cycle assessment which describes the raw material extraction (cradle), processing, and recycling or resuse as a raw or intermediate material portion of a product life cycle.

children.label: intermediate flow
children.definition: An input to or output from a unit process which requires further transformation to become a product flow.

children.label: cradle-to-grave
children.definition: A system boundary condition in a life cycle assessment which describes the raw material extraction (cradle), processing, and disposal as waste (grave) portion of a product life cycle.

children.label: quantitative reference (life cycle assessment)
children.definition: The baseline to which the size of the exchanges in the process relate.

children.label: reference product (life cycle assessment)
children.definition: Product of an activity for which a change in demand will affect the production volume of the activity (also known as the determining products in consequential modelling).

children.label: consequential life cycle assessment
children.definition: A life-cycle modeling method that describes the external consequences of decisions that change how material, energy and emissions flow within a discrete product or system.

children.label: marginal technology
children.definition: A technology or technology mix which is put in or out of operation due to changes in demand.

children.label: product flow
children.definition: The series of actions where products leave one product system and enter another product system.

children.label: cradle-to-gate
children.definition: A system boundary condition in a life cycle assessment which describes the raw material extraction (cradle) and processing (to the farm or factory gate) portion of a product life cycle.

children.label: industrial symbiosis
children.definition: Industrial symbiosis involves the flow of materials and energy through local and regional economies. Traditionally separate industries participate in industrial symbiosis through a collective approach to resource efficiency involving the exchange of materials, energy, and/or byproducts.

children.label: energy flow
children.definition: The movement and transformation of energy within and among ecological and industrial systems.

children.label: primary energy
children.definition: Primary energy should be used to designate those sources that only involve extraction or capture, with or without separation from contiguous material, cleaning or grading, before the energy embodied in that source can be converted into heat or mechanical work.

children.label: process energy
children.definition: Energy used in industry-specific processes, such as chemical reactors, steel furnaces, glass melters, casting, concentrators, distillation columns, etc. Categories of process energy include process heating (e.g., kilns, ovens, furnaces, strip heaters), process cooling and refrigeration, machine drive (e.g., motors, pumps associated with process equipment), electro-chemical processes (e.g., reduction process), and other direct process uses.

children.label: embodied energy
children.definition: The total energy required to produce a product is considered to be figuratively represented or embodied in the product itself.

children.label: energy conversion
children.definition: The change of energy from one form to another.

children.label: emergy
children.definition: Available energy of one kind previously required directly or indirectly to make a product or service (emjoule).

children.label: exergy
children.definition: The maximum amount of external-energy that could be drawn from a system or form of energy in relation to a certain reference environment. Exergy is not considered to be a form of energy but a designation of the quality of energy.

children.label: energy efficiency
children.definition: The ratio of the energy output to the total energy input of a process.

children.label: sustainable technology
children.definition: Technologies focusing on sustainability principles: resource conservation, reuse and recycling, energy efficiency, minimizing environmental impact and pollution reduction.

children.label: green chemistry
children.definition: Pollution prevention through the design of effective chemical products that have low or no toxicity and use of chemical processes that reduce or eliminate the use and generation of hazardous substances.

children.label: environmental product declaration
children.definition: A standardized (ISO 14025/TR) life-cycle assessment-based mechanism to communicate quantified life-cycle environmental information for a product.

children.label: product category rule
children.definition: A product category rule is a set of detailed rules, requirements, and guidelines for developing environmental declarations for a class of products. PCRs set the methods and life-cycle assessment boundary conditions that underpin an environmental product declaration.

children.label: sustainable manufacturing
children.definition: Sustainable manufacturing is the creation of manufactured products, through economically-sound processes that minimize negative environmental impacts while conserving energy and natural resources. Sustainable manufacturing also enhances employee, community, and product safety.

children.label: green infrastructure
children.definition: An interconnected framework of natural and/or engineered areas, structures, facilities, features or services providing environmentally friendly and sustainable benefits to people and communities.

children.label: United Nations Environment Programme
children.definition: International environmental program administered by the United Nations whose mission is to lead countries in efforts to care for the environment.

children.label: The Nature Conservancy
children.definition: An international conservation organization that purchases lands in order to preserve plants, animals and natural communities.

children.label: Conservation Reserve Program
children.definition: A major provision of the Food Security Act of 1985 designed to reduce erosion and protect water quality on up to 45 million acres of farmland. Under the program, enrolled landowners agree to convert environmentally sensitive land to approved conserving uses for 10-15 years. In exchange, the landowner receives an annual rental payment for up to 50 percent of the cost of establishing permanent vegetative cover.

children.label: Conservation of Private Grazing Land Program
environmental impact
children.definition: Any change to the environment, whether adverse or beneficial, wholly or partially resulting from an organization's environmental aspects.

children.label: environmental fate
children.definition: The destiny of any chemical, biological substance or pollutant after release into the environment.

children.label: environmental hazards
children.definition: Physical, chemical, biological or mechanical agents capable of causing harm to the environment, or a situation or event with the potential for adverse environmental impact.

children.label: marine debris
children.definition: Marine debris is defined as any persistent solid material that is manufactured or processed and directly or indirectly, intentionally or unintentionally, disposed of or abandoned into the marine environment or the Great Lakes.

children.label: municipal solid waste
children.definition: Locally collected garbage, includes residential, commercial, and institutional wastes.

children.label: mine spoil
children.definition: Earth and rock excavated from a mine.

children.label: sludge
children.definition: The solid or semi-solid residual waste remaining when liquid is removed during industrial waste treatment.

children.label: activated sludge
children.definition: Sludge that has been aerated and treated with microorganisms in order to accelerate microbial activity and the oxidation (decomposition) of organic compounds.

children.label: effluents
children.definition: Any liquid waste or byproduct that enters the environment from a point source.

children.label: greywater
children.definition: Wastewater from clothes, washing machines, showers, bathtubs, hand washing, lavatories and sinks.

children.label: mine tailings
children.definition: Material separated as refuse or separately treated as inferior in quality or value. The sand, gravel and cobbles which pass through sluices in placer mining. Refuse material resulting from the washing, concentration or treatment of ground ore. The residual after most of a valuable ore has been extracted.

children.label: green waste
children.definition: The vegetative portion of the waste stream arising from various sources including waste from domestic and commercial premises and municipal operations.

children.label: agricultural wastes
children.definition: Poultry and livestock manure, and residual materials in liquid or solid form generated from the production and marketing of poultry, livestock, furbearing animals, and their products. Also includes grain, vegetable, and fruit harvest residue.

children.label: food waste
children.definition: Food waste is a component of food loss and occurs when an edible item goes unconsumed, as in food discarded by retailers due to color or appearance and plate waste by consumers.

children.label: kitchen waste
children.definition: Food items left over from food preparation, cooking and serving in home or food service kitchens. These include peels, rinds, husks, meat scraps, bones, shells, etc. as well as leftover food from consumers' plates.

children.label: sewage
children.definition: The waste and wastewater discharged into sewers from homes and industry.

children.label: detritus
children.definition: Any loose material produced directly from disintegration processes. Organic detritus consists of material resulting from the decomposition of dead organic remains.

children.label: pollutants
children.definition: Any substance introduced into environment that has adverse effects on biological systems or organisms.

children.label: secondary pollutants
children.definition: Any pollutant that is formed by atmospheric reactions of precursor or primary emissions. An example of a secondary pollutant is ground-level ozone, which forms from chemical reactions involving airborne nitrogen oxides, airborne volatile organic compounds, and sunlight.

children.label: primary pollutants
children.definition: Any pollutant that is emitted into the atmosphere directly from its source and that retains the same chemical form. An example of a primary pollutant is dust that blows into the air from a landfill.

children.label: effluents
children.definition: Any liquid waste or byproduct that enters the environment from a point source.

children.label: dense nonaqueous phase liquids
children.definition: A DNAPL is one of a group of organic substances that are relatively insoluble in water and more dense than water. DNAPLs tend to sink vertically through sand and gravel aquifers to the underlying layer.

children.label: light non-aqueous phase liquids
children.definition: An LNAPL is one of a group of organic substances that are relatively insoluble in water and are less dense than water. LNAPLs, such as oil, tend to spread across the surface of the water table and form a layer on top of the water table.

children.label: bioerosion
children.definition: Removal or destruction of consolidated minerals or substrates by biological activity of organisms.

children.label: algal blooms
children.definition: A readily visible, high concentration of algal growth or aggregation of algae in or on the surface layer of a body of water.

children.label: deforestation
children.definition: The clearing of a forest, or portion of a forest, to convert it to non-forest use, such as a farm, subdivision, or power-line clearing.

children.label: ocean acidification
children.definition: Increased concentrations of carbon dioxide in sea water causing an increase in acidity of ocean waters (i.e., a reduction in ocean pH). Decrease in pH in coastal waters can be caused by dissolved inorganic carbon, dissolved and particulate organic carbon, and nutrients from riverine and estuarine sources.

children.label: land degradation
children.definition: Land degradation is defined as the reduction or loss of the biological or economic productivity and complexity of rain fed cropland, irrigated cropland, or range, pasture, forest and woodlands resulting from a combination of pressures, including land use and management practices.

children.label: fouling
children.definition: Becoming encrusted, clogged or choked with foreign matter.

children.label: pollution
children.definition: The presence in the environment of one or more contaminants, nuisances, and the like in sufficient quantities and of such characteristics and duration as to be injurious or irritating to human, plant, or animal life, to health, or to property, or to unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life or property.

children.label: soil pollution
children.definition: Modifications of soil features or, more generally, of its chemical and biological balance, caused by the discharge of polluting substances.

children.label: pollution load
children.definition: The quantity of pollutants present in an environment.

children.label: total maximum daily load
children.definition: TMDL is the calculation of the maximum amount of a pollutant allowed to enter a waterbody so that the waterbody will meet and continue to meet water quality standards for that particular pollutant. A TMDL determines a pollutant reduction target and allocates load reductions necessary to the source(s) of the pollutant.

children.label: chemical oxygen demand
children.definition: A measure of the amount of a water body's dissolved oxygen supply that would be used up in completely oxidizing added inorganic oxidizable compounds-such as in the oxidation of ammonia to nitrate. Biological oxygen demand (BOD) tests can only measure the biodegradable fraction of the total potential dissolved oxygen consumption by added wastes; however, COD tests may be used to measure the oxygen demand created by toxic organic or inorganic compounds as well as by biodegradable substances. A standard COD test, therefore, can be used to evaluate many industrial type wastes not readily analyzed for water quality factors by the sewage-oriented BOD test.

children.label: biochemical oxygen demand
children.definition: A measurement of the amount of organic pollution in water.

children.label: critical load
children.definition: A quantitative estimate of pollutant exposure below which significant adverse effects on the environment do not occur.

children.label: water pollution
children.definition: Any substance or energy form (heat, light, noise, etc.) which alters the state of a body of water from what would naturally occur. Especially associated with those altered states which human value judgements have decreed as bad.

children.label: thermal pollution
children.definition: Altering the amount of energy available in the environment by the addition of heat or cold. Most frequently this occurs in the form of the heat added by returning water which has been used for cooling purposes to a river, lake, estuary, bay or the ocean. However "thermal pollution" may also occur with the release of large volumes of the cold, deep water in reservoirs into warmer bodies of water.

children.label: air pollution
children.definition: Any substance or energy form (heat, light, noise, etc.) which alters the state of the air from what would naturally occur. Especially associated with those altered states whose physical, chemical, biological, psychological or aesthetic impacts have been decreed to be undesirable by human value judgments.

children.label: point source pollution
children.definition: Point source pollution refers to the pollution that comes from a specific, identifiable source, such as a pipe, channel, tank, pit or ditch.

children.label: nonpoint source pollution
children.definition: Pollution whose source is general rather than specific in location. It is widely used in reference to agricultural and related pollutants. For example, logging operations production of sediments, agricultural pesticide applications, automobile exhaust pollution, etc.

children.label: smog pollution
children.definition: Smog is the brownish haze that pollutes our air, particularly over cities in the summertime. Smog can make it difficult for some people to breathe and it greatly reduces how far we can see through the air. The primary component of smog is ozone, a gas that is created when nitrogen oxides react with other chemicals in the atmosphere, especially in strong sunlight.

children.label: agricultural pollution
children.definition: The liquid and solid wastes from all types of farming, including runoff from pesticides, fertilizers and feedlots; erosion and dust from plowing, animal manure and carcasses and crop residues and debris.

children.label: sediment contamination
children.definition: Contamination of sediments.

children.label: noise pollution
children.definition: Any sound which is unwanted or interferes with hearing other sounds.

children.label: soil degradation
children.definition: Soil degradation is defined as the process, which lowers (quantitatively or qualitatively) the current and/or the potential capability of soil to produce goods or services.

children.label: soil acidification
children.definition: Lowering of acid-neutralizing capacity (ANC) of the solid phase of a soil. It is basically a decrease in soil pH.

children.label: soil erosion
children.definition: The wearing away of the land surface by water, wind, ice, or other geologic agents.

children.label: tillage erosion
children.definition: The downslope movement of soil by tillage operations.

children.label: accelerated erosion
children.definition: Erosion much more rapid than normal erosion, natural erosion, or geologic erosion, and occurring primarily as a result of the influence of the activities of man or, in some cases, of other animals or natural catastrophes that expose bare surfaces (for example, fires).

children.label: wind erosion
children.definition: The process of detachment, transport, and deposition of soil by wind.

children.label: splash erosion
children.definition: The spattering of small soil particles caused by the impact of raindrops on wet soils. The loosened and spattered particles may or may not be subsequently removed by surface runoff.

children.label: gully erosion
children.definition: The erosion process whereby water accumulates in narrow ephemeral stream channels and, over short periods, removes the soil from this narrow area to considerable depths.

children.label: bank erosion
children.definition: Loss of bank material as individual particles or aggregates by fluvial and sub-aerial processes.

children.label: rill erosion
children.definition: The process by which numerous small channels, at the most only several inches deep, are formed on recently cultivated or exposed soils.

children.label: beach erosion
children.definition: The retreat of the shoreline of large lakes and coastal waters caused by wave action, shore currents or causes other than subsidence.

children.label: sheet erosion
children.definition: Soil erosion occurring from a thin, relatively uniform layer of soil particles on the soil surface.

children.label: eutrophication
children.definition: Process by which bodies of water become enriched in dissolved nutrients, e.g. phosphates, nitrates, nitrogenous compounds. The nutrients deplete the dissolved oxygen of the water by stimulating the growth of algae and other aquatic plant life.

children.label: habitat fragmentation
children.definition: A process during which larger areas of habitat are broken into a number of smaller patches of smaller total area, isolated from each other by a matrix of habitats unlike the original habitat.

children.label: pollen rain
children.definition: The fall of pollen grains and spores on to a particular area.

children.label: acid deposition
children.definition: A complex chemical and atmospheric phenomenon that occurs when emissions of sulfur and nitrogen compounds and other substances are transformed by chemical processes in the atmosphere, often far from the original sources, and then deposited on earth in either a wet or dry form. The wet forms, popularly called acid rain," can fall as rain, snow, or fog. The dry forms are acidic gases or particulates.

children.label: dry deposition
children.definition: The deposition of atmospheric gases and particulates to the Earth's surface in the absence of precipitation. Compare "wet deposition."

children.label: wet deposition
children.definition: A type of atmospheric deposition in which chemical substances and particulates from the atmosphere are incorporated into droplets and transferred to the earth's surface via rain, fog or snow. Compare "dry deposition".

children.label: environmental quality
children.definition: Properties and characteristics of the environment, either generalized or local, as they impinge on human beings and other organisms. Environmental quality is a general term which can refer to: varied characteristics such as air and water purity or pollution, noise, access to open space, and the visual effects of buildings, and the potential effects which such characteristics may have on physical and mental health.

children.label: ambient water quality
children.definition: Natural concentration of water quality constituents prior to mixing of either point or nonpoint source load of contaminants. Reference ambient concentration is used to indicate the concentration of a chemical that will not cause adverse impact to human health.

children.label: environmental protection
children.definition: Environmental protection includes prevention (avoidance) strategies to protect the environment from future damage or degradation; and control measures to restore and maintain environmental quality.

children.label: remediation
children.definition: The return to the original uncontaminated state.

children.label: soil remediation
children.definition: The removal of contaminants and pollutants from soil.

children.label: phytoremediation
children.definition: The use of plants to uptake, store, degrade, immobilize, transform, or volatilize harmful substances in order to mitigate damage to human health or the environment.

children.label: phytodesalination
children.definition: The cultivation of salt-resistant plants on salt-affected soil to improve the productivity of soil and vegetation cover.

children.label: bioaugmentation
children.definition: Introduction of specific microbes, nutrients, and other growth factors to enhance the biodegradative capacity of microbes already present in wastewater and other pollution degrading systems.

children.label: microbial bioremediation
children.definition: Use of (microbes) to clean up oil spills or remove other pollutants from soil, water, or wastewater.

children.label: land restoration
children.definition: The reestablishment and development of a plant cover. This may take place naturally through the reproductive processes of the existing flora or artificially through the direct action of man - e.g., afforestation, range reseeding.

children.label: forest restoration
children.definition: The process of returning degraded forests to their original structure, productivity, ecological integrity and species diversity.

children.label: biosequestration
children.definition: Capturing and storage of the atmospheric gases, especially, greenhouse gases by biological processes. This term is also used for sequesteration of copper, heavy metals.

children.label: environmental assessment
children.definition: An environmental analysis that evaluates the positive and negative changes to the environment conditions at and around a particular site of a proposed project. When conducted pursuant to the National Environmental Policy Act, a more detailed environmental impact statement may be prepared pending this general assessment.

children.label: environmental indicators
children.definition: A measurement, statistic or value that provides a proximate gauge or evidence of the effects of environmental management programs or of the state or condition of the environment.

children.label: vegetation index
children.definition: Linear combinations of spectral band responses in digital count, reflectance factor, or voltage to determine the vigor, greenness and/or biomass of the vegetation. Observations can be made by satelliteborne, aircraftborne, truck mounted, or hand held spectrometers.

children.label: normalized difference vegetation index
children.definition: A transformation of satellite-based measurements computed as the ratio of reflectance in the red and near-infrared portions of the spectrum. Reflectance in the red region decreases with increasing chlorophyll content of the plant canopy, while reflectance in the infrared increases with increasing wet plant biomass. The index value represents greenness, density, and vigor of vegetation.

children.label: leaf reflectance
children.definition: Leaf reflectance is defined as the proportion of the irradiated light that is reflected by the leaf.

children.label: fuel moisture index
children.definition: The fuel moisture index is a tool that is widely used to understand the fire potential for locations across the country. Fuel moisture is a measure of the amount of water in a fuel (vegetation) available to a fire, and is expressed as a percent of the dry weight of that specific fuel.

children.label: leaf area index
children.definition: The total area of the upper surface of leaves per unit area of ground that is directly below the plant.

children.label: global warming potential
children.definition: A measure of how much heat a substance can trap in the atmosphere. GWP can be used to compare the effects of different greenhouse gases. For example, methane has a GWP of 21, which means over a period of 100 years, 1 pound of methane will trap 21 times more heat than 1 pound of carbon dioxide (which has a GWP of 1).

children.label: energy recovery
children.definition: Saving or recovering energy which would otherwise be loss from processing or waste.

children.label: urban mining
children.definition: Systematic recovery or recycling of electronic and other related waste materials or compounds of commercial interest from urban sites.

children.label: advanced wastewater treatment
children.definition: Any treatment of sewage that goes beyond the secondary or biological water treatment stage and includes the removal of nutrients such as phosphorus and nitrogen and a high percentage of suspended solids.

children.label: composting
children.definition: The biodecomposition of organic material, such as animal wastes, plant residues or sludges, in the presence of air, by controlled methods including mechanical mixing and aerating.

children.label: home composting
children.definition: Refers to the diversion of food scraps and yard trimmings from the municipal waste stream through the onsite controlled decomposition of organic matter by micro-organisms (mainly bacteria and fungi) into a humus-like product. Backyard composting is excluded from recycling activities. Rather, it is considered source reduction because the composted materials never enter the municipal solid waste stream.

children.label: environmental audits
children.definition: Systematic, independent and objective reviews of verifiable information concerning environmental events, conditions, activities, or management systems.

children.label: dredging
children.definition: Dredging is the removal of sediments and debris from the bottom of lakes, rivers, harbors, and other water bodies.

children.label: environmental impact statements
children.definition: A document required of federal agencies by the National Environmental Policy Act for major projects or legislative proposals significantly affecting the environment. A tool for decision making, it describes the positive and negative effects of the undertaking and cites alternative actions.

children.label: environmental monitoring
children.definition: The monitoring of the level of toxins, chemical pollutants, microbial contaminants, or other harmful substances in the environment (soil, air, and water), workplace, or in the bodies of people and animals present in that environment.

children.label: environmental performance
children.definition: The measurable outcome of an organization's ability to meet environmental objectives and targets set forth in the organization's environmental plan or policy.

children.label: natural resource management
children.definition: The application of scientific and technical principles in the management of natural resources, such as land, water, soil, plants and animals, in order to meet ecological, economic, social and policy objectives.

children.label: hydraulic structures
children.definition: A manmade structure that serves the purpose of diverting, restricting, stopping, or otherwise controlling the natural flow of water.

children.label: dams (hydrology)
children.definition: A manmade barrier built across a body of water for the purpose of impounding water in a reservoir.

children.label: spillways
children.definition: A structure over or through which flow is discharged from a reservoir. If the rate of flow is controlled by mechanical means, such as gates, it is considered a controlled spillway. If the geometry of the spillway is the only control, it is considered an uncontrolled spillway.

children.label: fish ladders
children.definition: It is the combination of ingredients (structures, facilities, devices, operations, and measures) necessary to insure the safe and timely movement of fish past a barrier.

children.label: culverts
children.definition: A culvert is any kind of drain or pipe that allows unwanted water to flow under a road, trail etc. from one side to the other side.

children.label: water utilization
children.definition: Water that is used for a specific purpose, such as for domestic use, irrigation, or industrial processing. Water use pertains to human's interaction with and influence on the hydrologic cycle, and includes elements, such as water withdrawal from surface- and ground-water sources, water delivery to homes and businesses, consumptive use of water, water released from wastewater-treatment plants, water returned to the environment, and instream uses, such as using water to produce hydroelectric power.

children.label: water security
children.definition: Actions taken to assess and reduce consequences, threats, and vulnerabilities to potential terrorist attacks; to plan for and practice response to natural disasters, emergencies, and incidents; and to develop new security technologies to detect and monitor contaminants and prevent security breaches.

children.label: adaptive management
children.definition: A type of natural resource management in which decision making is an ongoing process. Monitoring the results of actions will provide a flow of information that may indicate the need to change a course of action. Scientific findings and the needs of society may also indicate the need to adapt resource management.

children.label: soil resource management
children.definition: The application of scientific and technical principles in the management of soil resources, in order to meet ecological, economic, social and policy objectives.

children.label: soil remediation
children.definition: The removal of contaminants and pollutants from soil.

children.label: natural resources conservation
children.definition: The protection, preservation, or restoration of natural resources such as forests, soil, water and wildlife.

children.label: in situ conservation
children.definition: Maintenance or conservation of an organism or gene resource within its native environment.

children.label: energy recovery
children.definition: Saving or recovering energy which would otherwise be loss from processing or waste.

children.label: conservation buffers
children.definition: Conservation buffers are strips or other areas with trees or grass that help control pollutants, erosion, or other environmental concerns.

children.label: vegetated waterways
children.definition: Grassed waterways are constructed graded channels that are seeded to grass or other suitable vegetation. The vegetation slows the water and the grassed waterway conveys the water to a stable outlet at a non-erosive velocity.

children.label: windbreaks
children.definition: Windbreaks are linear plantings of trees and shrubs designed to enhance crop production, protect people and livestock, and benefit soil and water conservation.

children.label: filter strips
children.definition: A strip or area of herbaceous vegetation that removes contaminants from overland flow.

children.label: wetland buffers
children.definition: A naturally vegetated area adjacent to a wetland or surface water that controls pollution and erosion, and maintains wetland function.

children.label: bunds
children.definition: Low ridges of earth built along the contour of the lower edge of a field to control soil erosion.

children.label: contour buffer strips
children.definition: Contour buffer strips are strips of perennial vegetation alternated down the slope with wider cultivated strips that are farmed on the contour. Contour buffers strips are usually narrower than the cultivated strips. Vegetation in strips consists of adapted species of grasses or a mixture of grasses and legumes.

children.label: riparian buffers
children.definition: Trees, shrubs and other vegetation located along the edge of rivers, streams and other waterways that filter pollution, prevent erosion and provide wildlife habitat.

children.label: ex situ conservation
children.definition: The process of protecting any species outside its natural habitat.

children.label: conservation areas
children.definition: An area of special interest due to its wildlife, natural features or historic value which is protected by laws or regulations in order to safeguard and conserve its character, viability and appearance for future generations.

children.label: conservation banks
children.definition: Conservation banks are permanently protected lands that contain natural resource values. These lands are conserved and permanently managed for species that are endangered, threatened, candidates for listing as endangered or threatened, or are otherwise species-at-risk. Conservation banks function to offset adverse impacts to these species that occurred elsewhere, sometimes referred to as off-site mitigation.

children.label: habitat conservation
children.definition: The preservation, maintenance, protection, restoration and enhancement of habitats for wild species.

children.label: data deficient species
children.definition: A taxon that is not evaluated for its risk of extinction by the International Union for Conservation of Nature due to lack of sufficient information.

children.label: extinct species
children.definition: Those species no longer known to exist after repeated search of the type localities and other known or likely places. Some species may be extinct in the wild but are being preserved by cultivation in gardens or as domesticated animals.

children.label: threatened species
children.definition: Any species which is likely to become an endangered species within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range and which has been designated in the Federal Register by the Secretary of Interior as a threatened species. (Endangered Species Act of 1973) This includes species categorized as rare, very rare, or depleted.

children.label: endangered species
children.definition: A species as defined in the Endangered Species Act, that is in danger of extinction through a significant portion of its range. A species classified as threatened is likely to become an endangered species.

children.label: conservation banking
children.definition: The application of the "mitigation" or "offset" approach to endangered species. When developers expect to harm an endangered species (whether listed at the federal or state level), they must "offset" or "mitigate" the damage through the creation of similar habitat elsewhere. Developers can mitigate by purchasing new property or modifying existing landholdings to support the impacted species.

children.label: afforestation
children.definition: The establishment of a tree crop on an area from which it has always or very long been absent.

children.label: even-aged management
children.definition: The application of a combination of actions that results in the creation of stands in which trees of essentially the same age grow together. The difference in age between trees forming the main canopy level of a stand usually does not exceed 20 percent of the age of the level of a stand at maturity. Regeneration in a particular stand is obtained during a short period at or near the time that a stand has reached the desired age or size for regeneration, and is harvested. Cutting methods producing even-aged stands are clearcut, shelterwood, or seed tree.

children.label: allowable cut
children.definition: The volume of timber which can be cut, under specified management plans during a given period.

children.label: uneven-aged management
children.definition: The course of actions involved in maintaining a forest or stand, composed of intermingling trees that differ markedly in age.

children.label: multiple use forestry
children.definition: any practice of forestry fulfilling two or more management objectives, such as production of timber and forest recreation.

children.label: sort yards
children.definition: A temporary location where logs from the forests or timber cutting sites are received and sorted on the basis of tree species, wood grades, wood types, size of logs etc., before being delivered to specialized manufacturing facilities.

children.label: wildlife damage management
children.definition: Activities designed to reduce the negative impact, conflict or threat of wildlife to other organisms, property, agricultural or natural resources, or to human society.

children.label: sustained yield management
children.definition: Management of resources to achieve the goal of obtaining a perpetual and steady supply of product.

children.label: ecosystem management
children.definition: A natural resource management strategy or plan which is ecologically-based and considers all organisms and their environment with regard to the social, physical, and economic needs of humans.

children.label: land management
children.definition: The intentional process of planning, organizing, programming, coordinating, directing, and controlling land use actions.

children.label: land evaluation
children.definition: The assessment of the inherent capability and managed suitability of land for man's use in agriculture, forestry, engineering, hydrology, regional planning, recreation, etc.

children.label: sustainable land management
children.definition: A process for the management of land resources that meets present needs without compromising future ecosystem services and land productivity.

children.label: land use
children.definition: The occupation or reservation of land or water area for any human activity or any defined purpose. It also includes use of the air space above the land or water.

children.label: zoning
children.definition: In general, the demarcation of a planning area by ordinance into zones and the establishment of regulations to govern the use of the land (commercial, industrial, residential, type of residential, etc.) and the location, bulk, height, shape, use, and coverage of structures within each zone.

children.label: ecological site descriptions
children.definition: An ecological site description (ESD) is a document describing the biotic and abiotic factors that influence the plant community. In includes information about landscape positions, climate, hydrology, plant community and soils information.

children.label: range management
children.definition: The art and science of planning and directing range use to obtain sustained maximum animal production, consistent with perpetuation of the natural resources.

children.label: pasture management
children.definition: The application of practices to keep pasture plants growing actively over as long a period as possible so that they will provide palatable feed of high nutritive value; to encourage the growth of desirable grasses and legumes while crowding out weeds, brush, and inferior grasses.

children.label: land restoration
children.definition: The reestablishment and development of a plant cover. This may take place naturally through the reproductive processes of the existing flora or artificially through the direct action of man - e.g., afforestation, range reseeding.

children.label: green belt (land management)
children.definition: Areas around villages, towns or cities in which development is strictly controlled and usually not permitted at all. A useful device for preventing the endless sprawl of towns or the coagulation of one town with another, providing townspeople with a welcome release from the strain of city life, and protecting the special character of some towns. The main deficiency of green belt preservation is that it encourages the leap-frogging of development over the green belt to the land beyond it.

children.label: watershed management
children.definition: The management of all the natural resources of a watershed to protect, maintain, or improve its water yields.

children.label: land retirement
children.definition: The process of taking agricultural land out of production.

children.label: landscape management
children.definition: The application of management principles to conserve, protect, enhance and restore landscape resources impacted by natural events and anthropogenic activities.

children.label: fisheries management
children.definition: The process to maintain aquatic resources that are important to fisheries, such as assessment of aquatic stocks, environmental monitoring and fishery regulation enforcement.

children.label: environment
children.definition: The complex of climatic, soil and biotic factors that act upon an organism or ecological community and ultimately determine its form and survival.

children.label: anaerobic conditions
children.definition: The complete absence, or temporary absence, of gaseous or dissolved elemental oxygen in a given environment.

children.label: dry environmental conditions
children.definition: Habitats or sites characterized by the limited water availability.

children.label: aseptic conditions
children.definition: An environmental state which is free of microorganisms, especially pathogens.

children.label: mesic conditions
children.definition: Habitats or sites characterized by moderate environmental conditions, neither decidedly wet (hydric conditions) nor dry (xeric conditions).

children.label: ambient temperature
children.definition: Temperature of the surrounding medium.

children.label: wet environmental conditions
children.definition: Habitats or sites with very moist or wet environments.

children.label: edaphic factors
children.definition: A condition of the soil, whether physical, biological or chemical, that influences the organisms and processes that occur in the soil.

children.label: biosphere
children.definition: That part of the earth's crust, waters and surrounding air-layer which is inhabited by living organisms.

children.label: aquatic environment
children.definition: Waters, including wetlands, that serve as habitat for interrelated and interacting communities and populations of plants and animals.

children.label: hydrology
children.definition: A science dealing with the properties, distribution, and circulation of water, specifically the study of water on the surface of land, in the soil and underlying rocks, and in the atmosphere, particularly with respect to evaporation and precipitation.

children.label: water interception
children.definition: The accumulation of water on vegetation and other above-ground plant surfaces that doesn't reach the ground and evaporates during and after rain or irrigation, etc.

children.label: hydraulic conductivity
children.definition: The capacity of a rock to transmit water. It is expressed as the volume of water at the existing kinematic viscosity that will move in unit time under a unit hydraulic gradient through a unit area measured at right angles to the direction of flow.

children.label: infiltration rate
children.definition: The maximum rate at which the soil under various specified conditions (including the presence of an already excess amount of water) can absorb falling rain or melting snow.

children.label: rain intensity
children.definition: The rate at which rain is falling at any given instant, usually expressed in inches per hour.

children.label: drawdown
children.definition: In hydrologic terms, the lowering of the surface elevation of a body of water, the water surface of a well, the water table, or the piezometric surface adjacent to the well, resulting from the withdrawl of water therefrom.

children.label: groundwater extraction
children.definition: The removal of groundwater usually for use as irrigation water, or following treatment, for drinking water.

children.label: groundwater recharge
children.definition: The addition of water to an aquifer that occurs naturally from infiltration of rainfall and from water flowing over earth materials that allow water to infiltrate below the land surface.

children.label: aquiclude
children.definition: An impermeable body of rock that may absorb water slowly, but does not transmit it.

children.label: aquifers
children.definition: A geologic formation or structure that transmits water in sufficient quantity to supply the needs for a water development, such as a well. The term "water-bearing" is sometimes used synonymously with "aquifer" when a stratum furnishes water for a specific use. Aquifers are usually saturated sands, gravel, fractured rock, or cavernous and vesicular rock.

children.label: groundwater
children.definition: Water within the earth that supplies wells and springs. Specifically, water in the zone of saturation where all openings in soils and rocks are filled-the upper surface of which forms the watertable.

children.label: plant available water
children.definition: The portion of water in a soil that can be absorbed by plant roots, that is, water held at a tension of less than 1500 kPa in the soil.

children.label: drainage water
children.definition: Any water, usually precipitation or irrigation water, that enters, interacts with, and then leaves a landscape.

children.label: ballast water
children.definition: Fresh or salt water taken in and released by ships to improve their stability. Organisms transported from one port to another may become invasive species (pests).

children.label: surface water
children.definition: All water naturally open to the atmosphere, such as rivers, lakes, ponds, streams, estuaries, impoundments, seas, etc.

children.label: ambient water
children.definition: Waterbodies in the environment in their current state (i.e., polluted or unpolluted).

children.label: brackish water
children.definition: A combination of fresh and salt water. Most of the water in the Bay is brackish.

children.label: recycled water
children.definition: Water that is used more than one time before it passes back into the natural hydrologic system.

children.label: evaporative demand
children.definition: The collective influence of aerial environment on the rate of evaporation of water from a given object, usually a plant or plant canopy.

children.label: surface water level
children.definition: The level of the surface of a body of water.

children.label: floods
children.definition: An overflow or inundation that comes from a river or other body of water and causes or threatens to cause property damage.

children.label: water table
children.definition: The upper surface of the groundwater or that depth below which the soil is saturated with water.

children.label: perched water table
children.definition: The upper surface of a local zone of soil water saturation held above the main body of groundwater by an impermeable layer or stratum, (usually clay) and separated from the main body of groundwater by an unsaturated zone.

children.label: surface storage
children.definition: The sum of detention storage and channel storage, representing, at any given moment, the total water enroute to an outlet from an area or watershed.

children.label: overland flow
children.definition: The rain storm or snow melt runoff water which flows over the ground surface as a thin layer - as opposed to the channelized (concentrated) runoff which occurs in rills and gulleys.

children.label: littoral zone
children.definition: Shallow area on or near the shore of a lake, river or other body of water.

children.label: euphotic zone
children.definition: Surface layer of a body of water where sufficient light penetrates to allow photosynthesis to occur, down to the depth at which the light intensity falls to 1% of incident light.

children.label: benthic zone
children.definition: The habitat at the bottom of a body of water, such as the sea floor or a lake bottom.

children.label: hydrologic cycle
children.definition: The circuit of water movement from the atmosphere through various stages or processes on the ground (such as precipitation, interception, runoff, infiltration, percolation, storage) and then back to the atmosphere again by evaporation, and transpiration.

children.label: infiltration (hydrology)
children.definition: The movement of water into the soil through pores or other openings, connoting flow into a soil in contradistinction to the word percolation which connotes flow through a soil.

children.label: hydrograph
children.definition: A graph showing variation in the water depth in a stream or the volume of water flowing past a point in a stream over a period of time.

children.label: evapotranspiration
children.definition: Combination of evaporation from free water surfaces and transpiration of water from plant surfaces to the atmosphere.

children.label: Soil and Water Assessment Tool model
suspended sediment
children.definition: Sediment which remains suspended in the water for a considerable period of time without coming in contact with the bottom.

children.label: sediment yield
children.definition: The quantity of sediment, measured in dry weight or by volume, transported through a stream cross-section in a given time. Sediment discharge consists of both suspended load and bedload.

children.label: natural resources
children.definition: All the parts of the Earth that are not human-made and which people use, like fish, trees, minerals, lakes, or rivers.

children.label: conservation areas
children.definition: An area of special interest due to its wildlife, natural features or historic value which is protected by laws or regulations in order to safeguard and conserve its character, viability and appearance for future generations.

children.label: conservation banks
children.definition: Conservation banks are permanently protected lands that contain natural resource values. These lands are conserved and permanently managed for species that are endangered, threatened, candidates for listing as endangered or threatened, or are otherwise species-at-risk. Conservation banks function to offset adverse impacts to these species that occurred elsewhere, sometimes referred to as off-site mitigation.

children.label: ephemeral streams
children.definition: A stream or portion of a stream that flows only in direct response to precipitation. It receives little or no water from springs and no long-continued supply from snow or other sources. Its channel is at all times above the water table.

children.label: stream channels
children.definition: The long, narrow depression in land where a natural stream of water flows or once flowed.

children.label: oxbow lakes
children.definition: Small, U-shaped lakes formed when a meander bend is cut off from the main stream channel of a river or stream.

children.label: ancient lakes
children.definition: Lakes consistently carrying water for more than one million years.

children.label: estuaries
children.definition: A water body having an open, natural connection with the sea and within which the sea water is measurably diluted by freshwater runoff.

children.label: aquifers
children.definition: A geologic formation or structure that transmits water in sufficient quantity to supply the needs for a water development, such as a well. The term "water-bearing" is sometimes used synonymously with "aquifer" when a stratum furnishes water for a specific use. Aquifers are usually saturated sands, gravel, fractured rock, or cavernous and vesicular rock.

children.label: renewable resources
children.definition: A natural resource that can be produced, regrown, or reused fast enough to keep up with how quickly it is used. Wind, tides, and solar energy, for example, are in no danger of running out and can be consumed by people virtually forever. In contrast, fossil fuels such as coal take millions of years to develop naturally and are considered nonrenewable.

children.label: experimental forests
children.definition: Timbered lands dedicated to research on forestry and forest management, silvicultural practices, forest ecosystems, wildlife habitats, and forest growth and development.

children.label: forest plantations
children.definition: Forest stand regenerated artificially either by sowing or planting.

children.label: demonstration forests
children.definition: Forests which provide models of forest ecology and exhibitions of various forest management techniques and silvicultural practices.

children.label: biofuels
children.definition: Gas or liquid fuel made from plant material (biomass). Includes wood, wood waste, wood liquors, peat, railroad ties, wood sludge, spent sulfite liquors, agricultural waste, straw, tires, fish oils, tall oil, sludge waste, waste alcohol, municipal solid waste, landfill gases, other waste, and ethanol blended into motor gasoline.

children.label: biodiesel
children.definition: A biofuel for use in diesel engines produced through the transesterfication of organically-derived oils or fats combined with alcohol (ethanol or methanol) in the presence of a catalyst. It may be used either as a replacement for or as a component of diesel fuel.

children.label: biogas
