children.definition: Gas resulting from the decomposition of organic matter under anaerobic conditions. The principal constituents are methane and carbon dioxide.

children.label: biocoal
children.definition: A biomass fuel processed by torrefaction of agricultural wastes such as wood residues into a high density, energy-concentrated fuel product in the form of pellets or briquettes.

children.label: bioethanol
children.definition: An alcohol fuel made by fermentation of carbohydrates in sugar- or starch-rich crops such as corn or sugarcane, or other biomass sources including grasses.

children.label: alternative fuels
children.definition: Substitutes for traditional liquid, oil-derived motor vehicle fuels like gasoline and diesel. Includes methanol, ethanol, biodiesel, compressed natural gas, and others. The alternatives are promoted for pollution reduction properties and/or to reduce dependency on imported oil.

children.label: fossil fuels
children.definition: Oil, natural gas, and coal. Fossil fuels were made in nature from ancient plants and animals, and today we burn them to make energy.

children.label: oil shale
children.definition: A kerogen-bearing, finely laminated brown or black sedimentary rock that will yield liquid or gaseous hydrocarbons on distillation. Oil shale, despite the name, does not actually contain oil, but rather a type of organic matter called kerogen, a precursor of oil that is converted to a type of crude oil when heated to about 450 – 500° C.

children.label: natural gas
children.definition: Hydrocarbons that exist as a gas or vapor at ordinary pressures and temperatures. Methane is the most important, but ethane, propane, or others may be present.

children.label: gas hydrate
children.definition: Naturally occurring "ice-like" combinations of natural gas and water that have the potential to provide an immense resource of natural gas from the world's oceans and polar regions. Gas hydrates are known to be widespread in permafrost regions and beneath the sea in sediments of outer continental margins. It is generally accepted that the volume of natural gas contained in the world's gas hydrate accumulations greatly exceeds that of known gas reserves.

children.label: liquefied natural gas
children.definition: Natural gas (primarily methane) that has been liquefied by reducing its temperature to -260 degrees Fahrenheit at atmospheric pressure.

children.label: coalbed methane
children.definition: Coalbed methane is methane contained in coal seams, and is often referred to as virgin coalbed methane, or coal seam gas.

children.label: petroleum
children.definition: Naturally occurring complex liquid hydrocarbons which, after distillation, yield combustible fuels, petrochemicals, and lubricants.

children.label: coal
children.definition: A readily combustible black or brownish-black rock whose composition, including inherent moisture, consists of more than 50 percent by weight and more than 70 percent by volume of carbonaceous material. It is formed from plant remains that have been compacted, hardened, chemically altered, and metamorphosed by heat and pressure over geologic time.

children.label: pulverized coal
children.definition: Coal that has been crushed to a fine dust in a grinding mill. It is blown into the combustion zone of a furnace and burns very rapidly and efficiently.

children.label: clean fuels
children.definition: Energy sources from which pollutants and other impurities have been removed by refining, purification, and other means, to produce fuels less conducive to pollution.

children.label: refuse derived fuels
children.definition: Fuel prepared from combustible components of municipal, industrial or commercial solid waste or refuse.

children.label: oil fields
children.definition: The surface area overlying an oil reservoir or reservoirs. The term usually includes not only the surface area, but also the reservoir, the wells, and the production equipment.

children.label: renewable energy sources
children.definition: Energy sources from natural resources, such as sunshine, wind, flowing water, biofuels, etc., which produce energy indefinitely without being depleted.

children.label: bioenergy
children.definition: The term "bioenergy" means biomass used in the production of energy (electricity; liquid, solid, and gaseous fuels; and heat).

children.label: biofuels
children.definition: Gas or liquid fuel made from plant material (biomass). Includes wood, wood waste, wood liquors, peat, railroad ties, wood sludge, spent sulfite liquors, agricultural waste, straw, tires, fish oils, tall oil, sludge waste, waste alcohol, municipal solid waste, landfill gases, other waste, and ethanol blended into motor gasoline.

children.label: biodiesel
children.definition: A biofuel for use in diesel engines produced through the transesterfication of organically-derived oils or fats combined with alcohol (ethanol or methanol) in the presence of a catalyst. It may be used either as a replacement for or as a component of diesel fuel.

children.label: biogas
children.definition: Gas resulting from the decomposition of organic matter under anaerobic conditions. The principal constituents are methane and carbon dioxide.

children.label: biocoal
children.definition: A biomass fuel processed by torrefaction of agricultural wastes such as wood residues into a high density, energy-concentrated fuel product in the form of pellets or briquettes.

children.label: bioethanol
children.definition: An alcohol fuel made by fermentation of carbohydrates in sugar- or starch-rich crops such as corn or sugarcane, or other biomass sources including grasses.

children.label: geothermal energy
children.definition: Heat from inside the Earth. People can use geothermal energy to heat buildings or produce electricity.

children.label: nuclear power
children.definition: Energy that comes from breaking apart the center (nucleus) of an atom.

children.label: cryptogenic species
children.definition: A species of unknown origin.

children.label: fauna
children.definition: The animal life of an area, "animal" being used in the broad sense to include birds, fish, reptiles, insects, mollusks, crustaceans, etc., in addition to mammals.

children.label: soil fauna
children.definition: Microscopic and macroscopic soil animals (mice, mites, nematodes, earthworms etc.), and some protozoans that spend at least part of their life in the soil.

children.label: introduced species
children.definition: Species that were intentionally or unintentionally brought by humans into a new geographic area or environment which is outside of their native range.

children.label: rare species
children.definition: A rare species, or subspecies, is one that, although not presently threatened with extinction, is in such small numbers, throughout its range, that it may be endangered if its environment worsens.

children.label: pioneer species
children.definition: The first members of a population to arrive in a new area, usually a bare, barren, uncolonized or disturbed environment. Pioneer species begin the process of ecological succession and are usually replaced by successional species.

children.label: wildlife
children.definition: Free, undomesticated species of plants and animals on earth.

children.label: gene banks
children.definition: The place where genetic material (cells, nucleic acids, etc.) is preserved. The main purpose is to conserve the DNA, RNA, genes, genome etc., for research or some other future use.

children.label: transcriptome
children.definition: An organism's complete set of mRNA molecules. The transcriptome may vary depending upon the condition and environment of the organism.

children.label: genotype mixtures
children.definition: A practice where two or more genotypes of a single species are used in combination, usually for the benefit of increased disease resistance, pest resistance, nitrogen fixation, etc.

children.label: purebreds
children.definition: Animals of known ancestry within a recognized breed that are eligible for registry in the official herdbook of that breed.

children.label: composite breeds
children.definition: Composites are a population made up of two or more component breeds, designed to retain heterosis (hybrid vigor) in future generations without crossbreeding, and maintained like a purebreed.

children.label: genotype
children.definition: The genetic constitution of an organism, cell, individual or taxon, as distinct from its physical appearance (i.e., phenotype).

children.label: biotypes
children.definition: Populations of organisms sharing an identical genotype.

children.label: ecotypes
children.definition: A subspecific group that is genetically adapted to a particular habitat.

children.label: chemotypes
children.definition: Chemically characterized parts of a population of morphologically indistinguishable organisms.

children.label: genetic background
children.definition: The genotypic base of a breeding line or population. Populations with a broad genetic base respond to selection more readily than those with a narrow base. Expression of a particular gene of interest will be affected by the residual genotype.

children.label: homozygosity
children.definition: An individual in which both alleles at a given locus are identical.

children.label: heterozygosity
children.definition: An individual having different alleles at one or more loci regarding a specific character.

children.label: gene dosage
children.definition: The number of copies of a given gene present in a cell or nucleus.

children.label: haplotypes
children.definition: The genetic constitution of individuals with respect to one member of a pair of allelic genes, or sets of genes that are closely linked and tend to be inherited together such as those of the major histocompatibility complex.

children.label: hemizygote
children.definition: An individual having only one allele at a given locus because of the loss of the other allele through a mutation (e.g., chromosome deletion).

children.label: clones
children.definition: A cell or organism that is grown from one cell of its parent and is genetically identical to the parent from which it is derived.

children.label: proteome
children.definition: The complete set of the proteins produced from the genetic code inside the cell.

children.label: germplasm
children.definition: The cells or tissues from which a new organism can be generated.

children.label: sialome
children.definition: The complete set of mRNA transcripts and proteins expressed in the salivary glands, especially of hematophagous arthropods such as ticks, fleas and mosquitoes.

children.label: hybrids
children.definition: Heterozygous offspring of two genetically different parents.

children.label: hybrid species
children.definition: A hybrid species can be a hybrid between two (or more) different species in the same genus, or it can be a hybrid between two (or more) different species in different genera.

children.label: hybrid genus
children.definition: A hybrid genus is the genus name used with a species that represents an intergeneric hybrid.

children.label: cybrids
children.definition: The viable cell resulting from the fusion of a cytoplast (cytoplasm remaining after the enculeation of a cell) with a whole cell.

children.label: DNA libraries
children.definition: A large collection of DNA fragments cloned from a given organism, tissue, organ, or cell type. It may contain complete genomic sequences (genomic library) or complementary DNA sequences, the latter being formed from messenger RNA and lacking intron sequences.

children.label: cDNA libraries
children.definition: Collections of cloned complementary DNA sequences synthesized from mRNA present in a cell or organism.

children.label: genomic libraries
children.definition: A form of gene library containing the complete DNA sequences present in the genome of a given organism. It contrasts with a cDNA library which contains only sequences utilized in protein coding (lacking introns).

children.label: metabolome
children.definition: The complete set of metabolites and endogenous small molecules involved in metabolism of whole cells. Metabolome varies with the physiological or developmental stage of the cell.

children.label: genome
children.definition: The complete set of genetic material in the chromosomes of an organism with its associated genes.

children.label: epigenome
children.definition: A network of chemical compounds surrounding DNA that modify the genome without altering the DNA sequences and have a role in determining which genes are active in a cell.

children.label: mitochondrial genome
children.definition: The genetic complement of mitochondria as represented in their DNA.

children.label: plastid genome
children.definition: The genetic complement of plastids as represented in their DNA.

children.label: chloroplast genome
children.definition: The genetic complement of chloroplasts as represented in their DNA.

children.label: apicoplast genome
children.definition: The genetic complement of apicoplasts as represented in their DNA.

children.label: genes
children.definition: The fundamental physical and functional unit of heredity. A gene is typically a specific segment of a chromosome and encodes a specific functional product (such as a protein or RNA molecule).

children.label: reporter genes
children.definition: Genes whose expression is easily detectable and therefore used to study promoter activity at many positions in a target genome. In recombinant DNA technology, these genes may be attached to a promoter region of interest.

children.label: lethal genes
children.definition: Genes whose loss of function or gain of function mutation leads to the death of the carrier prior to maturity. They may be essential genes required for viability, or genes which cause a block of function of an essential gene at a time when the essential gene function is required for viability.

children.label: major genes
children.definition: Genes that cause large trait differences between organisms that inherit different alleles.

children.label: suppressor genes
children.definition: Genes that have a suppressor allele or suppressor mutation which cancels the effect of a previous mutation, enabling the wild-type phenotype to be maintained or partially restored.

children.label: homeotic genes
children.definition: Genes that encode highly conserved transcription factors that control positional identity of cells (body patterning) and morphogenesis throughout development. Their sequences contain a 180 nucleotide sequence designated the homeobox, so called because mutations of these genes often results in homeotic transformations, in which one body structure replaces another. The proteins encoded by homeobox genes are called homeodomain proteins.

children.label: regulon
children.definition: In eukaryotes, a genetic unit consisting of a noncontiguous group of genes under the control of a single regulator gene. In bacteria, regulons are global regulatory systems involved in the interplay of pleiotropic regulatory domains and consist of several operons.

children.label: dominant genes
children.definition: Genes that influence the phenotype both in the homozygous and the heterozygous state.

children.label: modifiers (genes)
children.definition: Genes that control or change the phenotypic expressions of other genes by interfering with transcription.

children.label: essential genes
children.definition: Those genes found in an organism which are necessary for its viability and normal function.

children.label: cisgenes
children.definition: An identical copy of a gene that is derived either from the same species or from a different species that is sexually compatible.

children.label: unigenes
children.definition: Unique DNA sequences which may be obtained from expressed sequence tag (EST) analysis of a cDNA library.

children.label: operon
children.definition: In bacteria, a group of metabolically related genes, with a common promoter, whose transcription into a single polycistronic messenger RNA is under the control of an operator region.

children.label: suicide genes
children.definition: Genes that are used transgenically, i.e., via gene transfer techniques to induce cell death.

children.label: alleles
children.definition: Variant forms of the same gene, occupying the same locus on homologous chromosomes, and governing the variants in production of the same gene product.

children.label: pseudogenes
children.definition: Genes bearing close resemblance to known genes at different loci, but rendered non-functional by additions or deletions in structure that prevent normal transcription or translation. When lacking introns and containing a poly-A segment near the downstream end (as a result of reverse copying from processed nuclear RNA into double-stranded DNA), they are called processed genes.

children.label: synthetic genes
children.definition: Biologically functional sequences of DNA chemically synthesized in vitro.

children.label: gene components
children.definition: The parts of the gene sequence that carry out the different functions of the genes.

children.label: transcriptional regulatory elements
children.definition: Nucleotide sequences of a gene that are involved in the regulation of genetic transcription.

children.label: exons
children.definition: The parts of a transcript of a split gene remaining after the introns are removed. They are spliced together to become a messenger RNA or other functional RNA.

children.label: start codon
children.definition: A codon that directs initiation of protein translation (translation, genetic) by stimulating the binding of initiator tRNA (RNA, transfer, MET). In prokaryotes, the codons AUG or GUG can act as initiators while in eukaryotes, AUG is the only initiator codon.

children.label: codon usage
children.definition: The frequency of occurrence, in a specific organism's DNA sequence, of one of several potential synonymous codons that code for a particular amino acid. Frequently, there is a nonrandom pattern (bias) in the usage of a particular codon or codons over other synonymous codons.

children.label: stop codon
children.definition: Any codon that signals the termination of genetic translation (translation, genetic). Peptide termination factors bind to the stop codon and trigger the hydrolysis of the aminoacyl bond connecting the completed polypeptide to the tRNA. Terminator codons do not specify amino acids.

children.label: introns
children.definition: Sequences of DNA in the genes that are located between the exons. They are transcribed along with the exons but are removed from the primary gene transcript by RNA splicing to leave mature RNA. Some introns code for separate genes.

children.label: expressed sequence tags
children.definition: An Expressed Sequence Tag is a tiny portion of an entire gene that can be used to help identify unknown genes and to map their position within a genome.

children.label: duplicate genes
children.definition: Two identical genes showing the same phenotypic action but localized in different regions of a chromosome or on different chromosomes.

children.label: regulator genes
children.definition: Genes which control the activity of other genes by coding for proteins (repressors or activators) or RNAs which regulate gene expression or a physiological process in an organism.

children.label: tumor suppressor genes
children.definition: Genes that inhibit expression of the tumorigenic phenotype. They are normally involved in holding cellular growth in check. When tumor suppressor genes are inactivated or lost, a barrier to normal proliferation is removed and unregulated growth is possible.

children.label: major histocompatibility complex
children.definition: The genetic region which contains the loci of genes which determine the structure of the serologically defined (SD) and lymphocyte-defined (LD) transplantation antigens, genes which control the structure of the immune response-associated (Ia) antigens, the immune response (Ir) genes which control the ability of an animal to respond immunologically to antigenic stimuli, and genes which determine the structure and/or level of the first four components of complement.

children.label: structural genes
children.definition: A gene that encodes a protein with a chief function as part of a physical structure within a cell. This is in contrast to genes that encode proteins with a function that is enzymatic or regulatory.

children.label: oncogenes
children.definition: Genes whose gain-of-function alterations lead to neoplastic cell transformation. They include, for example, genes for activators or stimulators of cell proliferation such as growth factors, growth factor receptors, protein kinases, signal transducers, nuclear phosphoproteins, and transcription factors. A prefix of "v-" before oncogene symbols indicates oncogenes captured and transmitted by retroviruses; the prefix "c-" before the gene symbol of an oncogene indicates it is the cellular homolog (proto-oncogenes) of a v-oncogene.

children.label: multigene family
children.definition: A set of genes descended by duplication and variation from some ancestral gene. Such genes may be clustered together on the same chromosome or dispersed on different chromosomes.

children.label: chloroplast genes
children.definition: Those nucleic acid sequences that function as units of heredity which are located within the chloroplast DNA.

children.label: genomic islands
children.definition: Distinct units in some bacterial, bacteriophage or plasmid genomes that are types of mobile genetic elements. Encoded in them are a variety of fitness conferring genes, such as virulence factors (in "pathogenicity islands or islets"), antibiotic resistance genes, or genes required for symbiosis (in "symbiosis islands or islets"). They range in size from 10 - 500 kilobases, and their GC content and codon usage differ from the rest of the genome. They typically contain an integrase gene, although in some cases this gene has been deleted resulting in "anchored genomic islands".

children.label: landraces
children.definition: Traditional crop cultivars or animal breeds with enough genetic integrity to be morphologically identifiable that evolved with or have been genetically improved by traditional agriculturalists.

children.label: heirloom varieties
children.definition: Varieties whose germplasm has been conserved through the practice of retaining and passing down 1) seed or 2) vegetative propagules from generation to generation. The germplasm may be of significance to a specific region, community, culture or historic time period.

children.label: cultivars
children.definition: A contraction of "cultivated variety." It refers to a plant type within a particular cultivated species that is distinguished by 1 or more characters.

children.label: auxotrophs
children.definition: An organism that has mutated and has lost its ability to synthesize substances required for its growth and metabolism. The mutant organism requires specific substances as a nutritional supplement in order to grow.

children.label: cell lines
children.definition: Established cell cultures that have the potential to propagate indefinitely.

children.label: stem cells
children.definition: Undifferentiated cells that retain the ability to self-regenerate and differentiate into specialized cells.

children.label: adult stem cells
children.definition: Cells with high proliferative and self renewal capacities derived from adults.

children.label: myoblasts
children.definition: Embryonic (precursor) cells of the myogenic lineage that develop from the mesoderm. They undergo proliferation, migrate to their various sites, and then differentiate into the appropriate form of myocytes.

children.label: hematopoietic stem cells
children.definition: Progenitor cells from which all blood cells derive.

children.label: neural stem cells
children.definition: Self-renewing cells that generate the main phenotypes of the nervous system in both the embryo and adult. Neural stem cells are precursors to both neurons and neuroglia.

children.label: hematopoietic stem cells
children.definition: Progenitor cells from which all blood cells derive.

children.label: substitution lines
children.definition: Chromosome of a donor genotype is substituted into a recipient genotype.

children.label: isogenic lines
children.definition: Lines which differ genetically at only one or a few loci. Homozygous lines, clones, and identical twins are genetically identical at all loci.

children.label: serotypes
children.definition: Subdivision of a species or subspecies distinguishable from other such strains on the basis of antigenicity.

children.label: necromass
children.definition: The mass of dead organisms (microbes, plants, insects etc.) usually expressed per unit of land surface or water volume.

children.label: indigenous species
children.definition: Species that are native or naturally belonging to a particular geographic area or environment.

children.label: sedentary species
children.definition: Organisms which, at the harvest stage, either are immobile on or under the seafloor or are unable to move except in constant physical contact with the seafloor or the subsoil.

children.label: keystone species
children.definition: A species which plays an important ecological role in determining the overall structure and dynamic relationships within a biotic community. An evolutionary, component species of a biotic community whose presence is essential to the integrity and stability of a particular ecosystem.

children.label: migratory species
children.definition: A species that moves from one habitat or region to another on a regular or seasonal basis.

children.label: diadromous fish
children.definition: Fish that migrate between freshwater and saltwater for breeding or feeding.

children.label: catadromous fish
children.definition: Fish that migrate from freshwater to saltwater for reproduction.

children.label: anadromous fish
children.definition: Fish that migrate from saltwater to freshwater for reproduction.

children.label: potamodromous fish
children.definition: Potamodromous fish are species that are spawned in upstream freshwater habitats then migrate downstream (still in freshwater) as juveniles to grow into adults before migrating back upstream to spawn.

children.label: data deficient species
children.definition: A taxon that is not evaluated for its risk of extinction by the International Union for Conservation of Nature due to lack of sufficient information.

children.label: extinct species
children.definition: Those species no longer known to exist after repeated search of the type localities and other known or likely places. Some species may be extinct in the wild but are being preserved by cultivation in gardens or as domesticated animals.

children.label: threatened species
children.definition: Any species which is likely to become an endangered species within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range and which has been designated in the Federal Register by the Secretary of Interior as a threatened species. (Endangered Species Act of 1973) This includes species categorized as rare, very rare, or depleted.

children.label: endangered species
children.definition: A species as defined in the Endangered Species Act, that is in danger of extinction through a significant portion of its range. A species classified as threatened is likely to become an endangered species.

children.label: sibling species
children.definition: Species that are morphologically nearly identical and closely related genetically, but which are reproductively isolated and cannot interbreed sucessfully to produce fertile offspring.

children.label: vegetation types
children.definition: A plant community with distinguishable characteristics.

children.label: tundra
children.definition: Arctic or subarctic regions where tree growth is limited due to low temperatures, the short growing season, and the permanently frozen subsoil. Dominant vegetation consists of grasses, sedges, mosses, lichens, and dwarf shrubs and trees.

children.label: alpine tundra
children.definition: A tundra that is treeless due to the high altitude and can occur at any latitude.

children.label: chaparral
children.definition: Low, dense growth of shrubby vegetation or stunted and dwarf trees in arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern U.S. The coast range foothills of California are characterized by Atriplex canescens (four-wing saltbush), Ceanothus spp., and Arctostaphylos spp. (manzanita). In other places, dense thickets of Prosopis spp. (mesquite) and thickets of oaks may be called chaparral.

children.label: shrublands
children.definition: A growth of shrubs or small trees usually of a type undesirable to livestock or timber management.

children.label: forests
children.definition: Generally, an ecosystem characterized by a more or less dense and extensive tree cover. More particularly, a plant community predominantly of trees and other woody vegetation, growing more or less closely together.

children.label: boreal forests
children.definition: General term for northern coniferous forests.

children.label: virgin forests
children.definition: Natural forest virtually uninfluenced by human activity.

children.label: urban forests
children.definition: Urban forests include the trees in our yards, parks, public spaces, and along our streets. Though we don’t often think of them as forests, they provide many forest benefits, such as cleaner air and water. In addition to environmental benefits, urban forests increase property values, reduce home energy costs, block UV radiation, buffer wind and noise, provide shade and beautify our neighborhoods.

children.label: subalpine forests
children.definition: A transition zone from dense forest below treeline to alpine tundra above treeline.

children.label: demonstration forests
children.definition: Forests which provide models of forest ecology and exhibitions of various forest management techniques and silvicultural practices.

children.label: experimental forests
children.definition: Timbered lands dedicated to research on forestry and forest management, silvicultural practices, forest ecosystems, wildlife habitats, and forest growth and development.

children.label: secondary forests
children.definition: The first forest regenerated on land that was originally covered by primary forest which was drastically altered in structure by selective cutting or clearcutting for agricultural use.

children.label: old-growth forests
children.definition: Stands of forest trees of either seral or climax species growing singly or in association with other tree species. The stands are usually well past the age of maturity as defined by the culmination of mean annual increment and often exhibit characteristics of decadence. These characteristics may include, but are not limited to: low growth rates, dead and dying trees, snags, and down woody material. The stands are usually characterized by large diameter trees relative to species and site potential, multi-layered canopies, a range in tree diameter sizes, and the presence of understory vegetation. The specific attributes of an old-growth stand are primarily dependent on plant associations and forest cover type.

children.label: forest types
children.definition: Natural forests which are characterized by their dominant tree species.

children.label: sclerophyll forests
children.definition: Temperate forests composed predominantly of broad-leaved evergreen trees and shrubs in regions with warm rainy winters and dry hot summers.

children.label: montane forests
children.definition: The biogeographic zone made up of relatively moist cool upland slopes below timberline that is characterized by large evergreen trees as a dominant life form.

children.label: climax forests
children.definition: A plant community that represents for its locality and its environment the culminating stage of a natural succession.

children.label: forest borders
children.definition: A clear borderline between closed forest and nonforest area.

children.label: groves
children.definition: A small group of trees without underbrush, either planted or growing naturally.

children.label: grasslands
children.definition: Large land areas covered with grass typically used for grazing.

children.label: prairies
children.definition: Characterized by fertile soil, a mesic climate, and covered originally with coarse grasses, a prairie is an extensive, level or rolling, predominantly treeless grassland.

children.label: permanent grasslands
children.definition: Land used for five years or longer to grow grasses or herbaceous forage, either naturally or through cultivation.

children.label: steppes
children.definition: Arid land with xerophilous vegetation usually found in regions of extreme temperature range and loess soil.

children.label: meadows
children.definition: Natural or artificial grasslands primarily grown for making hay rather than for grazing livestock.

children.label: flood meadows
children.definition: Natural meadows located where river water or snowmelt provides seasonal flooding.

children.label: alpine meadows
children.definition: Natural meadows occurring at high altitude, near or above treeline.

children.label: treeline
children.definition: A zone where the normal growth of trees is limited; cold temperatures often combined with drought form the upper or arctic treeline, and drought combined with hot temperatures form lower or arid treeline.

children.label: cerrado
children.definition: A type of plains community characterized by a mosaic of vegetation ranging from tropical broadleaf woodlands to scrublands to savannas, with a pronounced dry season. The second largest of Brazil's major biomes (after Amazonia), it spreads across the central plateau and comprises 21% of Brazil's land area.

children.label: heathlands
children.definition: A vegetation type dominated by low growing woody plants from the Ericaceae family and typically found in uncultivated open land with poor acidic or peaty soils.

children.label: savannas
children.definition: A tropical or subtropical biome, consisting mainly of coarse grasses with scattered shrubs and trees due to distinct wet and dry seasons; often a transitional zone between a grassland and a woodland.

children.label: taiga
children.definition: Taiga is a humid, subarctic biogeographic region of northern Asia, Europe, and North America. It is characterized by coniferous evergreens growing with a groundcover of lichens and mosses, although some broadleaf trees (aspens, birches, willows) adapted to the cold climate do occur. The taiga is found just south of tundra.

children.label: biomass
children.definition: The total amount of organic matter present in an organism, population, ecosystem or given area.

children.label: woody biomass
children.definition: The trees and woody plants, including limbs, tops, needles, leaves, and other woody parts, grown in a forest, woodland, or rangeland environment, that are the by-products of forest management.

children.label: microbial biomass
children.definition: The total amount of organic matter present in microorganisms typically in a particular environment.

children.label: flora
children.definition: The sum total of the kinds of plants in an area at one time.

children.label: microbiome
children.definition: The full collection of microbes (bacteria, fungi, virus, etc.) that naturally exist within a particular biological niche such as an organism, soil, a body of water, etc.

children.label: biodiversity
children.definition: The variety of all native living organisms and their various forms and interrelationships.

children.label: species diversity
children.definition: The variety of species in an area. It includes not only the number of species in the area but also their relative abundance and spatial distribution. Species richness is one component of species diversity, but not the only determinant.

children.label: species richness
children.definition: Number of different species in a community.

children.label: species abundance
children.definition: The number of individuals per species in a particular place at a particular time.

children.label: botanical composition
children.definition: The percentage of plant species that comprise a plant community.

children.label: agrobiodiversity
children.definition: Agrobiodiversity is a fundamental feature of farming systems around the world. It encompasses many types of biological resources tied to agriculture, including: genetic resources - the essential living materials of plants and animals; edible plants and crops, including traditional varieties, cultivars, hybrids, and other genetic material developed by breeders; and livestock (small and large, lineal breeds or thoroughbreds) and freshwater fish; soil organisms vital to soil fertility, structure, quality, and soil health; naturally occurring insects, bacteria, and fungi that control insect pests and diseases of domesticated plants and animals; agroecosystem components and types (polycultural/monocultural, small/large scale, rainfed/irrigated, etc.) indispensable for nutrient cycling, stability, and productivity; and 'wild' resources (species and elements) of natural habitats and landscapes that can provide services (for example, pest control and ecosystem stability) to agriculture. Agrobiodiversity therefore includes not only a wide variety of species, but also the many ways in which farmers can exploit biological diversity to produce and manage crops, land, water, insects, and biota.

children.label: mycobiota
children.definition: The total sum of all kinds of fungi present in a particular area at one time.

children.label: flagship species
children.definition: Popular, charismatic, socially appealing species that serve as symbols and rallying points to evoke public sympathy and stimulate conservation awareness and action.

children.label: urban cool island
children.definition: An urban area that is cooler than its surrounding rural area during the daytime.

children.label: heat island
children.definition: An area with air temperatures measurably greater than that of its surroundings. Urban areas form "heat islands".

children.label: riparian areas
children.definition: The area of land next to a body of water. Riparian areas form the transition between terrestrial and aquatic environments.

children.label: national parks
children.definition: An area of land and/or sea usually owned and administered by a national government and is protected from human exploitation and development. The area is intended to provide environmentally and culturally sensitive scientific, educational and recreational opportunities.

children.label: watersheds
children.definition: The land area that drains water to a particular stream, river, or lake. It is a land feature that can be identified by tracing a line along the highest elevations between two areas on a map, often a ridge.

children.label: reserve networks
children.definition: A collection of protected areas, sites or nature reserves which conserve species or habitat types in order to protect biological diversity and the greatest number of species.

children.label: residential areas
children.definition: Land used primarily for permanent dwellings, such as houses, apartments, and housing developments, including adjacent facilities such as underground and surface utilities, access streets and alleys, and other servicing structures, appurtenances, and measures.

children.label: open space
children.definition: Any relatively unobstructed area which may intentionally be left undeveloped or unimproved, such as for amenity or conservation purposes.

children.label: land
children.definition: A term denoting the entire complex of surface and near-surface attributes of the solid portions of the surface of the earth which are significant to man. Water bodies occurring within land masses are included with land in some land classification systems.

children.label: arid lands
children.definition: Barren, desert or semi-desert land that is typically dry with less than 10 inches of annual precipitation.

children.label: landfills
children.definition: A site where solid waste materials are disposed of on land - supposedly in a manner which prevents their escape into-or pollution of-the surrounding environment. The waste is spread in layers, then compacted to the smallest practical volume and covered with compacted soil at the end of each working day.

children.label: public lands
children.definition: Land for which the title and control rests with a government - Federal, state, regional, county, or municipal.

children.label: land cover
children.definition: The physical materials characterizing the surface of land. These include trees, grasses or other vegetation, rocks as well as human-modified structures. Land cover is often observed by remote sensing technology.

children.label: tribal lands
children.definition: Land owned or traditionally belonging to a group of families, clans, or generations.

children.label: agricultural land
children.definition: Land used primarily for the production of farm commodities. The categories of "agricultural land" are: cropland and pasture; orchards, groves, vineyards, bush fruits, and horticultural areas (such as nurseries); feeding operations; and other.

children.label: cropland
children.definition: Land used primarily for the production of adapted cultivated and close-growing crops for harvest, alone or in association with sod crops, and open land recently in such uses. In some states land in fruit and nut trees, grapes, etc., is designated orchard land or vineyard land rather than "cropland".

children.label: farm area
children.definition: The area of agricultural land used for farming (crop and livestock production).

children.label: pastures
children.definition: An area devoted to the production of forage (introduced or native) and harvested by grazing.

children.label: annual pastures
children.definition: A pasture consisting of introduced forage species planted for only one year or season's duration.

children.label: plantations
children.definition: Agricultural land, usually of large size, in which one or more major crop(s) or stand of plants (such as cotton, tobacco, sugar cane, oil palms, forest trees, etc.) is established either by sowing or planting.

children.label: forest plantations
children.definition: Forest stand regenerated artificially either by sowing or planting.

children.label: woodlots
children.definition: A small parcel of forested land used for production of wood or other forest products.

children.label: rangelands
children.definition: Land on which the historic climax plant community is predominantly grasses, grasslike plants, forbs, or shrubs. Includes lands revegetated naturally or artificially when routine management of that vegetation is accomplished mainly through manipulation of grazing. Rangelands include natural grasslands, savannas, shrublands, most deserts, tundra, alpine communities, coastal marshes, and wet meadows.

children.label: badlands
children.definition: A land type consisting of steep or very steep barren land, usually broken by an intricate maze of narrow ravines, sharp crests, and pinnacles resulting from serious erosion of soft geologic materials.

children.label: forest land
children.definition: A part of land covered with forest or set aside for the cultivation of forests.

children.label: wildland
children.definition: Lands unoccupied by crops, pastures, urban, residential, industrial or transportation facilities. Lands over which man has not extended his complete and permanent domain with his bulldozers, plows and asphalt spreaders.

children.label: grazing lands
children.definition: (1) Collective term used by NRCS for rangeland, pastureland, grazed forest land, native and naturalized pasture, hayland, and grazed cropland. Although grazing is generally a predominate use, the term is used independent of any use. (2) Land used primarily for production of forage plants maintained or manipulated primarily through grazing management. Includes all lands having plants harvestable by grazing without reference to land tenure, other land uses, management, or treatment practices.

children.label: landscapes
children.definition: The characteristics that distinguish a certain geographic area including its physical environment, biological composition, and anthropogenic activities.

children.label: cultural landscape
children.definition: The aspect of the face of the earth which results from the presence of man - the natural landscape modified by man.

children.label: wilderness
children.definition: Any land uncultivated and uninhabited by humans.

children.label: community gardens
children.definition: Community gardens are collaborative projects on shared open spaces where participants share in the maintenance and products of the garden, including healthful and affordable fresh fruits and vegetables.

children.label: wetlands
children.definition: An area that is saturated by surface or ground water with vegetation adapted for life under those soil conditions.

children.label: seasonal wetlands
children.definition: Ephemeral wetlands formed during the wettest time of year which dry and disappear with seasonal change. These seasonal wetlands are important in amphibian life cycles and as a source of food and water for wildlife.

children.label: fens
children.definition: Wetlands that accumulate peat deposits. Fens are less acidic than bogs, deriving most of their water from groundwater rich in calcium and magnesium.

children.label: peatlands
children.definition: Peatland is a generic term for an extensive tract of wetland where peat has formed. They develop more extensively in northern areas where water drainage is blocked, precipitation is retained, and organic matter decomposition is slowed.

children.label: marshes
children.definition: Wetlands that do not accumulate appreciable peat deposits and are dominated by herbaceous vegetation.

children.label: salt marshes
children.definition: Typically, transitional areas between land and ocean, where the salinity and level of the water are dependent on the tides. However, there are also inland salt marshes in arid areas where the water has a high salt level due to evaporation. Salt water marshes are dominated by salt tolerant (halophytic) vegetation. They are environmentally delicate areas, extremely vulnerable to pollution.

children.label: swamps
children.definition: Wetlands dominated by woody vegetation but without appreciable peat deposits. Swamps may be fresh or salt water and tidal or non-tidal.

children.label: bogs
children.definition: Wetlands that accumulate appreciable peat deposits. Bogs depend primarily on precipitation for their water source, and are usually acidic and rich in plant residue with a conspicuous mat of living green moss.

children.label: wildland-urban interface
children.definition: The common area where human settlements and built structures are intermixed and/or adjacent to undeveloped land in which the vegetation is permitted to grow without significant human interference.

children.label: US National Forest System
children.definition: A nationally significant system of Federally owned units of forest, range, and related land consisting of national forests, purchase units, national grasslands, land utilization project areas, experimental forest areas, experimental range areas, designated experimental areas, other land areas, water areas, and interests in lands that are administered by the USDA Forest Service or designated for administration through the Forest Service. Also see Section 11 of Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 (P.L. 93-378, 88 Stat. 476, 16 U.S.C. 1609).

children.label: nonrenewable resources
children.definition: Natural resources that cannot be regenerated or grown at a sustainable rate to meet demand, including fossil fuels, metals, and minerals.

children.label: ecology
children.definition: A branch of science concerned with the interrelationships of organisms and their cycles and rhythms, community development and environments-especially as manifested by natural structure, interaction between different kinds of organisms, geographic distributions, and population alterations.

children.label: ecosystems
children.definition: A natural community of plants, animals, and other living organisms and the physical environment in which they live and interact.

children.label: agroecosystems
children.definition: Land used for crops, pasture, and livestock; the adjacent uncultivated land that supports other vegetation and wildlife; and the associated atmosphere, the underlying soils, groundwater, and drainage networks.

children.label: phytobiome
children.definition: All organisms (insects, plants, animals, microbes, etc.) living in, on and around plants in an environment and influencing plant health and productivity.

children.label: aquatic ecosystems
children.definition: Interaction of living organisms with the physical or chemical environment in a body of water.

children.label: marine ecosystems
children.definition: Interaction of living organisms with the physical or chemical environment in a body of saltwater.

children.label: lotic systems
children.definition: An aquatic ecosystem in which the water is actively moving, such as is found in streams and rivers. Compare lentic systems.

children.label: lentic systems
children.definition: An aquatic ecosystem in which the water is still and not rapidly moving, such as is found in ponds and swamps. Compare lotic systems.

children.label: biotic factors
children.definition: Any living thing or a component derived from them, or a process caused by them that might affect other organisms and the environment.

children.label: rhizosphere
children.definition: The soil surrounding and directly influenced by plant roots.

children.label: soil food webs
children.definition: The interconnected community of organisms living all or part of their lives in the soil.

children.label: edaphic factors
children.definition: A condition of the soil, whether physical, biological or chemical, that influences the organisms and processes that occur in the soil.

children.label: community ecology
children.definition: The study of the relationships among communities of organisms and their environment.

children.label: limnology
children.definition: The study of the physical, chemical, hydrological, and biological aspects of fresh water bodies.

children.label: drone congregation areas
children.definition: Specific areas in the air where queens and drones fly to mate.

children.label: biocenosis
children.definition: A group of interacting organisms that live in a particular habitat and form an ecological community.

children.label: climax communities
children.definition: The final or stable biotic community in a developmental series (sere); it is self-perpetuating and in equilibrium with the physical habitat.

children.label: plant communities
children.definition: The various plant populations (species) that live in the same habitat or environment, typically with one or more dominant species.

children.label: even-aged stands
children.definition: A class of forest or stand composed of trees of about the same age. The maximum age difference admissible is generally 10 to 20 years. Compare uneven-aged stands.

children.label: uneven-aged stands
children.definition: A class of forest or stand composed of intermingled trees or groups of trees that differ markedly in age. Compare even-aged stands.

children.label: stand basal area
children.definition: Cross-sectional area of trees measured at breast height (4.5 feet from ground level), or of grasses and shrubs measured 1 inch from ground level used to determine phytomass. Basal area is usually expressed as square units per unit area.

children.label: stand composition
children.definition: The proportion of each plant species in a managed unit, such as a forest, sward or crop.

children.label: stand density
children.definition: The average total basal area per acre of a given stand.

children.label: sward
children.definition: A mixture of grass, legumes and other species which are close-growing and form a dense stand that covers the ground.

children.label: habitats
children.definition: The natural environment where an organism, population or community lives, including biotic and abiotic factors.

children.label: habitat connectivity
children.definition: Landscape connectivity is defined as the degree to which the spatial configuration of the landscape facilitates or disturbs movement, dispersal, and gene flow between habitat patches.

children.label: niches
children.definition: How an organism fits into the ecosystem--where it lives, what it consumes, what consumes it, and how it interacts with all biotic and abiotic factors.

children.label: rhizosphere
children.definition: The soil surrounding and directly influenced by plant roots.

children.label: phyllosphere
children.definition: The three-dimensional microenvironment surrounding a leaf.

children.label: biodiversity
children.definition: The variety of all native living organisms and their various forms and interrelationships.

children.label: species diversity
children.definition: The variety of species in an area. It includes not only the number of species in the area but also their relative abundance and spatial distribution. Species richness is one component of species diversity, but not the only determinant.

children.label: species richness
children.definition: Number of different species in a community.

children.label: species abundance
children.definition: The number of individuals per species in a particular place at a particular time.

children.label: botanical composition
children.definition: The percentage of plant species that comprise a plant community.

children.label: agrobiodiversity
children.definition: Agrobiodiversity is a fundamental feature of farming systems around the world. It encompasses many types of biological resources tied to agriculture, including: genetic resources - the essential living materials of plants and animals; edible plants and crops, including traditional varieties, cultivars, hybrids, and other genetic material developed by breeders; and livestock (small and large, lineal breeds or thoroughbreds) and freshwater fish; soil organisms vital to soil fertility, structure, quality, and soil health; naturally occurring insects, bacteria, and fungi that control insect pests and diseases of domesticated plants and animals; agroecosystem components and types (polycultural/monocultural, small/large scale, rainfed/irrigated, etc.) indispensable for nutrient cycling, stability, and productivity; and 'wild' resources (species and elements) of natural habitats and landscapes that can provide services (for example, pest control and ecosystem stability) to agriculture. Agrobiodiversity therefore includes not only a wide variety of species, but also the many ways in which farmers can exploit biological diversity to produce and manage crops, land, water, insects, and biota.

children.label: nutritional ecology
children.definition: Nutritional ecology is the study of the relationship of an organism with its environment through nutritional interactions.

children.label: ecological zones
children.definition: Large biogeographical units of land/water that are characterized by their distinct species and communities. The major ecozones are further divided into many smaller ecoregions which share similar natural communities, climate, meteorological factors, topography, elevation, soil types, edaphic factors, and/or other physical characteristics.

children.label: ecoregions
children.definition: Physical regions which are characterized by their distinct species and communities and are also classified by their similar physical characteristics such as climate, meteorological factors, topography, elevation, soil types, etc.

children.label: Australasian region
children.definition: Region generally including the islands of the southwest Pacific Ocean, Australia, New Zealand, New Guinea and the Malay Archipelago.

children.label: ecological resilience
children.definition: The level of disturbance that an ecosystem can undergo without crossing a threshold to a situation with different structure or outputs. Resilience depends on ecological dynamics as well as the organizational and institutional capacity to understand, manage, and respond to these dynamics.

children.label: ecosystem respiration
children.definition: The total respiration of all organisms living in a given ecosystem.

children.label: nestedness
children.definition: A measurement or analysis of the patterns of species distribution within naturally fragmented habitats (such as islands). A nested pattern is where the species composition in fragmented habitats is a subset of those habitats with more species.

children.label: ecological competition
children.definition: The simultaneous demand by two or more organisms or species for a necessary resource in their environment (e.g., nutrients, space, water).

children.label: colonizing ability
children.definition: Ability of an organism (e.g, microbe, plant, animal) to survive and thrive in a new habitat.

children.label: plant competition
children.definition: The simultaneous demand of two or more plant individuals or species for a necessary resource in their environment (e.g., nutrients, water, space).

children.label: ecological invasion
children.definition: interspecific competition where native species are competing with nonnative species for resources (e.g., nutrients, space, water, etc.)

children.label: competitive exclusion
children.definition: The displacement or elimination of a species from its habitat by another species through interspecific competition.

children.label: host preferences
children.definition: The selection of a particular host species by a pest, pathogen or parasite based on the host's capacity to provide nutrition, shelter or otherwise support development.

children.label: phenology
children.definition: The study of periodic biological phenomena with relation to climate, particularly seasonal changes. These phenomena can be used to interpret local seasons and the climatic zones.

children.label: host-pathogen relationships
children.definition: The interactions between a host and a pathogen, usually resulting in disease.

children.label: edge effects
children.definition: Ecological characteristics associated with the junction between two dissimiliar habitat types or ecosystems affecting the population structure and biological traits of the associated plant or animal communities.

children.label: biological corridors
children.definition: Areas connecting separated habitats which allow movement to and access by wild species. These spaces make gene flow between isolated populations possible and may ameliorate negative effects of habitat fragmentation.

children.label: net ecosystem exchange
children.definition: A measurement of the quantity of carbon entering and leaving the ecosystem, usually associated with carbon dioxide flux from the ecosystem to the atmosphere.

children.label: host range
children.definition: The variety of different host species that provide nourishment, shelter or are otherwise associated with a specific parasite or symbiont.

children.label: primary productivity
children.definition: A measure of the rate at which new organic matter is formed and accumulated through photosynthesis and chemosynthesis activity of producer organisms (chiefly, green plants). The rate of primary production is estimated by measuring the amount of oxygen released (oxygen method) or the amount of carbon assimilated by the plant (carbon method).

children.label: parasite load
children.definition: Measure of the number of the parasites present in a host organism.

children.label: primary succession
children.definition: The natural development of the vegetation on a newly produced bare area (e.g., sand dunes, lava flows, river banks) that have not previously borne vegetation.

children.label: secondary succession
children.definition: A secondary succession is initiated by natural or artificial disruption of a previously established stable or climax community by some major environmental disturbance (e.g., forest fire, hurricane, farming) and leading to a marked change in the stable community.

children.label: ecological balance
children.definition: A state of dynamic equilibrium within a community of organisms in which genetic, species, and ecosystem diversity remain relatively stable, subject to gradual changes through natural succession.

children.label: net ecosystem production
children.definition: The difference between the amount of organic carbon fixed in an ecosystem by photosynthesis (gross primary productivity) and total ecosystem respiration. NEP represents the total amount of organic carbon available for storage or loss in the ecosystem. Whether NEP is greater or less than zero determines if an ecosystem is autrophic or heterotrophic.

children.label: secondary productivity
children.definition: The amount of carbon incorporated by heterotrophs (animals, saprophytes, herbivores, etc.) from organic matter (food) per unit area over time.

children.label: ecosystem engineering
children.definition: The physical modification, maintenance, or creation of habitats by ecosystem engineers.

children.label: myiasis
children.definition: The invasion of living tissues of man and other mammals by dipterous larvae.

children.label: insect outbreaks
children.definition: A marked increase in the population of an insect pest.

children.label: breeding sites
children.definition: Habitats where animals go to mate and reproduce.

children.label: fungus gardens
children.definition: Mass of spongy plant material mixed with fungal mycelia, often seen in certain insect nests.

children.label: phytosociology
children.definition: The branch of plant ecology concerning the composition, distribution, characteristics and interrelationships of plant species living in plant communities.

children.label: botanical composition
children.definition: The percentage of plant species that comprise a plant community.

children.label: vegetation structure
children.definition: The overall morphology and architecture of a plant community, such as the vertical layers of plants of different heights in a agroforestry system, the presence/absence of gaps in the forest canopy, or the horizontal spacing of individual plants.

children.label: plant strata
children.definition: The vertical structure of plant communities.

children.label: canopy
children.definition: The more or less continuous layer of vegetation formed by the foliage and branches of plants.

children.label: forest canopy
children.definition: The more or less continuous cover of upper branches and foliage of forest trees which is exposed to sunlight and restricts the sunlight from reaching the understory and the forest floor.

children.label: understory
children.definition: A layer of vegetation (such as saplings in a forest) that is below the canopy but have cleared the ground level vegetation.

children.label: overstory
children.definition: That portion of the foliage of plants and trees forming the upper or uppermost layer of a plant community.

children.label: plant competition
children.definition: The simultaneous demand of two or more plant individuals or species for a necessary resource in their environment (e.g., nutrients, water, space).

children.label: plant communities
children.definition: The various plant populations (species) that live in the same habitat or environment, typically with one or more dominant species.

children.label: even-aged stands
children.definition: A class of forest or stand composed of trees of about the same age. The maximum age difference admissible is generally 10 to 20 years. Compare uneven-aged stands.

children.label: uneven-aged stands
children.definition: A class of forest or stand composed of intermingled trees or groups of trees that differ markedly in age. Compare even-aged stands.

children.label: stand basal area
children.definition: Cross-sectional area of trees measured at breast height (4.5 feet from ground level), or of grasses and shrubs measured 1 inch from ground level used to determine phytomass. Basal area is usually expressed as square units per unit area.

children.label: stand composition
children.definition: The proportion of each plant species in a managed unit, such as a forest, sward or crop.

children.label: stand density
children.definition: The average total basal area per acre of a given stand.

children.label: sward
children.definition: A mixture of grass, legumes and other species which are close-growing and form a dense stand that covers the ground.

children.label: forest growth
children.definition: change in timber volume that occurs over an interval of time.

children.label: forest litter
children.definition: The uppermost layer of organic debris on the ground under a vegetation cover-i.e., essentially the freshly fallen or only slightly decomposed vegetable material, mainly from foliage but also bark fragments, twigs, flowers, fruits, etc.

children.label: dead wood
children.definition: Dead branches or completely dead standing trees resulting from natural processes or anthropogenic activity such as logging.

children.label: slash
children.definition: Debris left over after logging, pruning, thinning or brush cutting; includes logs, chips, bark, branches, stumps and broken understory trees or brush.

children.label: snags
children.definition: Standing dead trees from which the leaves and most of the branches have fallen.

children.label: coarse woody debris
children.definition: Large dead woody material such as fallen trees and branches in various stages of decomposition that provides nutrient capital to forest resources and serves as habitat in forest and riparian ecosystems. May serve a geomorphic function in stream channels.

children.label: biofilm
children.definition: A thin layer of living cells, usually microorganisms, coating a surface.

children.label: ecotones
children.definition: Zones of transition where two or more ecosystems meet.

children.label: fire regime
children.definition: The history and pattern of fire frequency, intensity, severity, seasonality and size in a particular ecosystem.

children.label: fire severity
children.definition: The degree to which an ecosystem is altered or disrupted by fires. Fire severity is dependent upon the product of fire intensity and duration, and incorporates both active fire behavior and immediate post-fire effects on the environment.

children.label: fire history
children.definition: The history of fire frequency in a geographical area.

children.label: fuel loading
children.definition: The quantity of living or dead vegetation that is easily ignited in a given area. Loading is usually expressed in tons per acre.

children.label: fuels (fire ecology)
children.definition: Living or dead vegetation that can be ignited.

children.label: population ecology
children.definition: The field of ecology dealing with the dynamics of populations within species, and the patterns in space and time of the interactions of these populations with environmental factors.

children.label: socioeconomic status
children.definition: A stratum of people with similar position and prestige; includes social stratification. Social class is measured by criteria such as education, occupation, and income.

children.label: social mobility
children.definition: The upward or downward movement of individuals or groups into different positions in a social hierarchy based on wealth, income, occupation, education, social power, or any other scarce social resources. A society with a high rate of social mobility and good opportunities for upward social mobility is not egalitarian but does maximize opportunities for one individual or group to get more of the society's scarce resources than other individuals or groups can get.

children.label: social inequality
children.definition: A condition in which various members of a society have unequal amounts of income, prestige, and social power.

children.label: demographic statistics
children.definition: Concept limited to the population statistics of any population.

children.label: carrying capacity
children.definition: The maximum population that may be sustained in an ecosystem or management unit without adverse effects to the environment.

children.label: population dynamics
children.definition: The pattern of any process, or the interrelationship of phenomena, which affects growth or change within a population.

children.label: species recruitment
children.definition: The addition of new individuals into a population.

children.label: Allee effect
children.definition: Decline in population growth rate at low population sizes.

children.label: residential density
children.definition: The average number of families living on one acre of land in a given area. "Gross residential density" is obtained by dividing all land in a defined area used for residences, streets, local schools, local parks and local shopping facilities into the total number of families is said area."Net residential density" is determined by dividing the total number of families in a defined area by the total acreage of all parcels of land within the area that is used for residential purposes.

children.label: animal density
children.definition: In biology, populations are groups of individuals belonging to the same species that live in the same region at the same time. Animal density is a measure of the number of organisms that make up a population in a defined area.

children.label: morbidity
children.definition: State of being ill or diseased. Morbidity is the occurrence of a disease or condition that alters health and quality of life.

children.label: basic reproduction number
children.definition: The expected number of new cases of an infection caused by an infected individual, in a population consisting of susceptible contacts only.

children.label: mortality
children.definition: All deaths reported in a given population.

children.label: winterkill
children.definition: The death of all or a part of a population due to exposure to cold temperatures or inclement weather conditions during winter.

children.label: fish kills
children.definition: The sudden death of fish due to natural causes, pollutants, or environmental factors such as the reduction of the dissolved oxygen concentration in a body of water.

children.label: socioeconomic status
children.definition: A stratum of people with similar position and prestige; includes social stratification. Social class is measured by criteria such as education, occupation, and income.

children.label: social mobility
children.definition: The upward or downward movement of individuals or groups into different positions in a social hierarchy based on wealth, income, occupation, education, social power, or any other scarce social resources. A society with a high rate of social mobility and good opportunities for upward social mobility is not egalitarian but does maximize opportunities for one individual or group to get more of the society's scarce resources than other individuals or groups can get.

children.label: social inequality
children.definition: A condition in which various members of a society have unequal amounts of income, prestige, and social power.

children.label: population viability
children.definition: The probability that enough individuals in a population will survive to reproductive age to prevent extirpation of the population.

children.label: population
children.definition: A group of individuals defined by a particular set of characteristics, e.g., organisms of a particular species living in a given region or area.

children.label: low-income population
children.definition: A group whose level of living, which may be defined by a specific income level, is below the community standard.

children.label: at-risk population
children.definition: Any group which is more susceptible to adverse events than the general population, due their health or any economic, physical, emotional, environmental, or social factors.

children.label: immunocompromised population
children.definition: A population of individuals with a weakened immune system, making them susceptible to illness or infection.

children.label: voltinism
children.definition: The number of broods or generations a population of a species produces within a year.

children.label: heterotrophs
children.definition: Organisms whose main source of nutrition is complex organic matter. Contrast with autotrophs.

children.label: algivores
children.definition: An organism that feeds on algae.

children.label: photoheterotrophs
children.definition: Organisms that depend on light for energy and complex organic matter for carbon.

children.label: carnivores
children.definition: An organism (plant or animal) that feeds on animal substances.

children.label: insectivores
children.definition: An organism (plant or animal) that mainly feeds on insects.

children.label: piscivores
children.definition: An organism that mainly feeds on fish.

children.label: detritivores
children.definition: An organism (plant or animal) that feeds on the organic remains or other organic debris from autotrophic (mostly plant) organisms.

children.label: heterotrophic bacteria
children.definition: Bacteria whose main source of nutrition is complex organic matter.

children.label: omnivores
children.definition: An organism that feeds on both animal and plant substances.

children.label: parasites
children.definition: Invertebrate organisms that live on or in another organism (the host), and benefit at the expense of the other. Traditionally excluded from definition of parasites are pathogenic bacteria; fungi; viruses; and plants; though they may live parasitically.

children.label: mycoparasites
children.definition: A fungus which is parasitic on another fungus.

children.label: lice
children.definition: Ectoparasites of animals and humans which feed on host blood, skin or feathers.

children.label: helminths
children.definition: Wormlike parasites of animals, including parasitic stages of nematodes, cestodes, trematodes, acanthocephalans and nematomorphs, especially those parasitizing the intestines of vertebrates.

children.label: endoparasitoids
children.definition: Parasitoids which at some time in their life history develop inside the body of their host. Immature developmental stages may be endoparasitoids, with adults being free-living.

children.label: predators
children.definition: An organism that preys on other organisms that are usually weaker.

children.label: birds of prey
children.definition: A bird that kills and eats other animals for food.

children.label: mesopredators
children.definition: A mesopredator is a middle trophic level predator in the food web which is both predator and prey.

children.label: predatory insects
children.definition: Several species of insect preying upon other insects, mites, etc.

children.label: fungivores
children.definition: A fungivore is defined as a fungus-eating organism.

children.label: herbivores
children.definition: An animal that feeds on plant substances.

children.label: seed insects
children.definition: Insects usually feeding inside developing flowers, ovaries or seeds and damage them before they fully develop.

children.label: frugivores
children.definition: Organisms that feed primarily on fruits.

children.label: granivores
children.definition: An animal that mainly feeds on the seeds and grains of plants.

children.label: prey species
children.definition: Any animal that is killed or hunted by another animal (predator) for food, etc.

children.label: forage fish
children.definition: A forage fish is any fish eaten by large predatory fish, seabirds or marine mammals. They are usually abundant and often swim in large schools.

children.label: autotrophs
children.definition: Organisms which are capable of producing organic matter from inorganic materials by utilizing energy, such as chlorophyll-containing plants and bacteria. Contrast with heterotrophs.

children.label: autotrophic bacteria
children.definition: Bacteria that are capable of synthesizing their organic matter from inorganic materials.

children.label: natural enemies
children.definition: Living organisms found in nature that kill, weaken, or reduce the reproductive potential of other organisms.

children.label: coprophilous organisms
children.definition: An organism feeding on feces of another organism.

children.label: dung beetles
children.definition: Beetles feeding on dung.

children.label: dung flies
children.definition: Flies that breed in and feed on animal dung.

children.label: mycorrhizae
children.definition: Symbiotic combination (dual organism) of the mycelium of fungi with the roots of plants (plant roots). The roots of almost all higher plants exhibit this mutually beneficial relationship, whereby the fungus supplies water and mineral salts to the plant, and the plant supplies carbohydrates to the fungus. There are two major types of mycorrhizae: ectomycorrhizae and endomycorrhizae.

children.label: endomycorrhizae
children.definition: A mycorrhiza penetrating into the associated root and ramifying between the cells; generally formed by phycomycete fungi.

children.label: ectomycorrhizae
children.definition: A mycorrhiza growing in a close web on the surface of an associated root; generally formed by basidiomycete fungi.

children.label: mutualism
children.definition: A type of symbiotic relationship in which both species benefit.

children.label: actinorhizae
children.definition: Symbiotic nitrogen-fixing organs composed of root tissue and actinomycete bacteria such as Frankia, which may be found on trees in the genera Alnus, Casuarina and Elaeagnus.

children.label: commensalism
children.definition: A type of symbiotic relationship in which one species benefits and other is unaffected.

children.label: phoresy
children.definition: A commensal relationship in which one organism is transported by a larger organism of another species.

children.label: inquilinism
children.definition: A commensal relationship in which the inquiline species acts as a social parasite of the host species, often living in the nest or depositing eggs in galls formed by other insects.

children.label: kleptoplasty
children.definition: A phenomenon in which chloroplasts or plastids from algae or other organisms are sequestered by a host.

children.label: food webs
children.definition: The complex network of linked food chains, trophic levels and feeding relationships among organisms in an ecosystem.

children.label: food chain
children.definition: The transfer of food energy from the initial source in plants through a series of organisms by repeated eating and being eaten. "Food chains" are not isolated sequences but are interconnected with one another. The interlocking pattern is often spoken of as the food web.

children.label: soil food webs
children.definition: The interconnected community of organisms living all or part of their lives in the soil.

children.label: trophic levels
