children.definition: A description of community structure based on the relationship between the production, consumption, and decomposition of energy (food) by organisms. Primary producers such as algae, herbivores such as deer, and carnivores such as wolves represent three different trophic levels.

children.label: symbionts
children.definition: An organism that is associated with an organism of another species and participating in a beneficial symbiotic relationship.

children.label: methanotrophs
children.definition: Microorganisms that metabolize methane as their only source of carbon and energy under aerobic or anaerobic conditions.

children.label: hyperparasitism
children.definition: Parasitism in which a secondary parasite parasitizes a previously existing (primary) parasite in a host.

children.label: social parasitism
children.definition: The coexistence in the same nest or colony of two insect or animal species, of which one is parasitically dependent upon the other.

children.label: multiparasitism
children.definition: Parasitism of a single host by different species of parasites.

children.label: brood parasitism
children.definition: The parasitic laying of eggs in the nests of other animals without providing parental care as observed in birds and other animals.

children.label: superparasitism
children.definition: Parasitism of a host by more parasites of the same species than can survive to maturity. It can be caused by one ovipositional event, or by subsequent ovipositions by the same female or by conspecific females.

children.label: kleptoparasitism
children.definition: Habitual stealing of already procured prey or food by individuals of one species from individuals of another species. It is mostly observed in birds, insects and other animals.

children.label: auxotrophs
children.definition: An organism that has mutated and has lost its ability to synthesize substances required for its growth and metabolism. The mutant organism requires specific substances as a nutritional supplement in order to grow.

children.label: agroecology
children.definition: The design, development and management of sustainable agroecosystems based on the application of ecological principles while considering existing social, cultural, and economic factors of farming communities.

children.label: agroecosystems
children.definition: Land used for crops, pasture, and livestock; the adjacent uncultivated land that supports other vegetation and wildlife; and the associated atmosphere, the underlying soils, groundwater, and drainage networks.

children.label: agroecological zones
children.definition: Land areas classified by their biophysical attributes, (such as rainfed soil moisture availability, temperature, length of growing period), in order to cluster land use types into homogenous units for agricultural production considerations.

children.label: environmental exposure
children.definition: The exposure to potentially harmful chemical, physical, or biological agents in the environment or to environmental factors that may include ionizing radiation, pathogenic organisms, or toxic chemicals.

children.label: cumulative exposure
children.definition: The sum total of all exposure to biological, chemical or physical agents via relevant routes, pathways and sources.

children.label: maternal exposure
children.definition: Exposure of the female parent, human or animal, to potentially harmful chemical, physical, or biological agents in the environment or to environmental factors that may include ionizing radiation, pathogenic organisms, or toxic chemicals that may affect offspring. It includes pre-conception maternal exposure.

children.label: exposure pathways
children.definition: The route in which a population is exposed to a biological, chemical or physical agent from its source.

children.label: dermal exposure
children.definition: Contact between a physical, chemical or biological agent and the skin.

children.label: oral exposure
children.definition: Contact between a potentially harmful physical, chemical or biological agent (e.g., pesticide, microbe, heavy metal, drug etc.) and an organism by ingestion.

children.label: direct contact
children.definition: A mode of exposure to a biological, chemical or physical agent between an exposed and a susceptible surface in which surfaces touch.

children.label: primary contact
children.definition: Initial exposure to a biological, chemical or physical agent.

children.label: secondary contact
children.definition: Exposure to a biological, chemical or physical agent following initial exposure.

children.label: indirect contact
children.definition: A mode of exposure to a biological, chemical or physical agent involving vectors or fomites.

children.label: occupational exposure
children.definition: Contact with a physical, chemical or biological agent in the workplace.

children.label: inhalation exposure
children.definition: Contact between a physical, chemical or biological agent and an organism through the respiratory system.

children.label: second-hand smoke exposure
children.definition: Involuntary environmental inhalation for a nonsmoker to tobacco smoke.

children.label: airborne transmission
children.definition: The spread of a biological, chemical or physical agent through the air, typically over distances greater than one meter from the source.

children.label: absorption barrier
children.definition: Any surface that may retard the rate of penetration of a biological, chemical, or physical agent into an organism. Examples include the skin and the linings of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

children.label: aggregate exposure
children.definition: The sum total of all exposure to a specific biological, chemical or physical agent via relevant routes, pathways and sources.

children.label: acceptable daily intake
children.definition: The amount of a substance to which an organism can be exposed on a daily basis over an extended period of time (usually a lifetime) without suffering deleterious effects.

children.label: exposure duration
children.definition: The frequency and length of time an organism is in contact with a biological, physical or chemical agent.

children.label: chronic exposure
children.definition: Contact made between a chemical, physical or biological agent and an organism habitually for a long period of time (typically more than a year).

children.label: acute exposure
children.definition: Contact made between a chemical, physical or biological agent and an organism for a short period of time (typically less than a day).

children.label: subchronic exposure
children.definition: Contact made between a chemical, physical or biological agent and an organism for an intermediate period of time (typically a matter of days or months).

children.label: absorbed dose
children.definition: The amount of a substance penetrating across an absorption barrier (the exchange boundaries) of an organism, via either physical or biological processes.
